content.definition: Albuminocytologic dissociation is a specific cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) finding characterized by an elevated protein level in the presence of a normal (or near-normal) white blood cell count, classically associated with the inflammation and nerve root demyelination of [[guillain_barre_syndrome]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Inflammation of the spinal nerve roots allows plasma proteins to leak into the CSF, but the blood-nerve barrier remains intact enough to prevent significant cellular infiltration.
  • Diagnostic Criteria: Elevated CSF protein (>45 mg/dL) with normal WBC count (<10 cells/µL).
  • Associations: The hallmark laboratory finding of [[guillain_barre_syndrome]] (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy).
  • USMLE Tip: If the vignette describes ascending paralysis and asks for the CSF finding, look for "High protein, low cells."
content.takeAway: Albuminocytologic dissociation reflects the breakdown of the blood-nerve barrier at the level of the nerve roots, allowing protein leakage without pleocytosis, distinguishing [[guillain_barre_syndrome]] from infectious etiologies like [[meningitis]].

content.definition: The Vesicular Monoamine Transporter (VMAT) is an integral membrane protein responsible for packaging monoamines (such as [[dopamine]], [[norepinephrine]], and [[serotonin]]) from the cytosol into synaptic vesicles, thereby enabling their subsequent release into the synaptic cleft and protecting them from degradation by [[monoamine_oxidase]].
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Transports monoamines into presynaptic vesicles against a concentration gradient using a proton gradient.
  • Pharmacology: Inhibited by drugs like [[tetrabenazine]], [[deutetrabenazine]], and [[reserpine]].
  • Clinical Use: Inhibition of VMAT2 depletes dopamine stores, which is therapeutic for hyperkinetic movement disorders like [[huntington_disease]] (chorea) and [[tardive_dyskinesia]].
  • Adverse Effects of Inhibition: Depression, sedation, and parkinsonism due to monoamine depletion.
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that Reserpine irreversibly blocks VMAT, while Tetrabenazine is a reversible inhibitor used for Huntington's chorea.
content.takeAway: VMAT is the gatekeeper for neurotransmitter storage; its inhibition leads to the depletion of presynaptic monoamines (dopamine, norepinephrine), making it a target for treating hyperkinetic disorders at the risk of causing depression or parkinsonism.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cytosolic Dopamine] -->|VMAT2| B[Synaptic Vesicle]; B -->|Release| C[Synaptic Cleft]; D[Tetrabenazine] --x|Inhibits| A;

content.definition: The Lateral Geniculate Nucleus (LGN) is a specific sensory relay nucleus within the [[thalamus]] that receives visual information from the [[optic_tract]] and projects it via the optic radiations to the [[primary_visual_cortex]] (calcarine sulcus) in the occipital lobe.
content.atAGlance:
• Input: [[optic_tract]] (carrying fibers from the ipsilateral temporal retina and contralateral nasal retina).
  • Output: Optic radiations (Geniculocalcarine tract) to the [[primary_visual_cortex]] (V1).
  • Function: Processing and relaying visual data (Vision).
  • Structure: 6 layers; Layers 1, 4, 6 receive contralateral input; Layers 2, 3, 5 receive ipsilateral input.
  • USMLE Tip: Mnemonic: L is for Light (Vision) = LGN.
content.takeAway: The Lateral Geniculate Nucleus is the primary thalamic processing center for the visual system, acting as the gateway between the retina and the [[visual_cortex]].
content.mermaid: graph LR; A[Retina] --> B[Optic Nerve]; B --> C[Optic Chiasm]; C --> D[Optic Tract]; D --> E[Lateral Geniculate Nucleus]; E --> F[Optic Radiations]; F --> G[Primary Visual Cortex];

content.definition: The Medial Geniculate Nucleus (MGN) is a specific sensory relay nucleus within the [[thalamus]] that receives auditory information from the [[inferior_colliculus]] and projects it via the auditory radiations to the [[primary_auditory_cortex]] in the temporal lobe.
content.atAGlance:
• Input: [[inferior_colliculus]] (via the brachium of the inferior colliculus).
  • Output: Auditory radiations to the [[primary_auditory_cortex]] (Transverse temporal gyri of Heschl).
  • Function: Relaying auditory information (Hearing).
  • USMLE Tip: Mnemonic: M is for Music (Hearing) = MGN.
content.takeAway: The Medial Geniculate Nucleus serves as the mandatory thalamic relay station for all ascending auditory information en route to the cortex.
content.mermaid: graph LR; A[Cochlea] --> B[Brainstem Nuclei]; B --> C[Inferior Colliculus]; C --> D[Medial Geniculate Nucleus]; D --> E[Primary Auditory Cortex];

content.definition: The Ventral Posterolateral Nucleus (VPL) is the major somatosensory relay nucleus of the [[thalamus]] responsible for transmitting sensation from the body (vibration, pain, pressure, proprioception, temperature) to the primary somatosensory cortex.
content.atAGlance:
• Input: [[spinothalamic_tract]] (pain/temp) and [[dorsal_column_medial_lemniscus]] (touch/proprioception).
  • Output: Primary [[somatosensory_cortex]] (Postcentral gyrus).
  • Information Type: Somatosensory input from the Body (neck down).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from VPM (Face). Remember: VPL is for the Periphery (Body).
content.takeAway: The Ventral Posterolateral Nucleus integrates all somatosensory modalities from the body and relays them to the cortex; lesions here result in contralateral hemianesthesia of the body.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Spinothalamic Tract] --> B[VPL]; C[Medial Lemniscus] --> B; B --> D[Somatosensory Cortex];

content.definition: The Ventral Posteromedial Nucleus (VPM) is the sensory relay nucleus of the [[thalamus]] responsible for transmitting sensation from the face and taste input to the primary somatosensory cortex.
content.atAGlance:
• Input: [[trigeminal_nerve]] (via trigeminothalamic tract) and Gustatory pathway.
  • Output: Primary [[somatosensory_cortex]].
  • Information Type: Somatosensory input from the Face and Taste.
  • USMLE Tip: Mnemonic: VPM = Makeup goes on the Face (or Mouth for taste).
content.takeAway: The Ventral Posteromedial Nucleus serves as the exclusive thalamic relay for facial sensation and taste, funneling trigeminal and gustatory inputs to the cortex.

content.definition: Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms are minute aneurysms that form in the small, penetrating vessels of the brain (specifically the [[lenticulostriate_arteries]]) due to chronic uncontrolled hypertension, serving as the primary cause of spontaneous deep [[intraparenchymal_hemorrhage]].
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Chronic [[hypertension]] leads to lipohyalinosis and fibrinoid necrosis of small vessel walls, weakening them and causing micro-dilations.
  • Location: Deep brain structures: [[basal_ganglia]] (putamen), [[thalamus]], pons, and cerebellum.
  • Clinical Consequence: Rupture leads to hypertensive intraparenchymal hemorrhage (hemorrhagic stroke), causing contralateral hemiparesis or sensory loss depending on location.
  • Imaging: Too small to be seen on angiography (unlike [[saccular_aneurysm]]); diagnosis is inferred by the presence of deep hemorrhage on CT.
  • USMLE Tip: Contrast with Saccular (Berry) aneurysms: Charcot-Bouchard = Chronic Hypertension (small vessels, intraparenchymal bleed); Berry = Structural defect (Circle of Willis, Subarachnoid bleed).
content.takeAway: Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms are the pathological link between chronic hypertension and deep hemorrhagic strokes, specifically affecting the lenticulostriate arteries supplying the basal ganglia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Chronic Hypertension] --> B[Lipohyalinosis]; B --> C[Vessel Wall Weakening]; C --> D[Charcot-Bouchard Aneurysm]; D --> E[Rupture]; E --> F[Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage];

content.definition: Noncommunicating (Obstructive) Hydrocephalus is a form of hydrocephalus caused by a structural blockage of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow within the ventricular system, preventing CSF from communicating with the subarachnoid space and leading to dilation of the ventricles upstream of the obstruction.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiologies: [[aqueductal_stenosis]], colloid cysts (foramen of Monro), tumors (e.g., [[ependymoma]], [[medulloblastoma]]), or congenital malformations ([[dandy_walker_malformation]], [[chiari_malformation]]).
  • Pathophysiology: Physical obstruction prevents CSF egress → Accumulation → Increased [[intracranial_pressure]] (ICP).
  • Imaging: CT/MRI shows dilation of ventricles proximal to the block (e.g., dilated lateral/3rd ventricles with a normal 4th ventricle suggests aqueductal stenosis).
  • Clinical Presentation: Headache, papilledema, nausea/vomiting, macrocephaly (in infants).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[communicating_hydrocephalus]] (decreased absorption, all ventricles dilated). Look for "triventricular" dilation as a sign of aqueductal blockage.
content.takeAway: Noncommunicating Hydrocephalus implies a physical blockade within the ventricular system (often the cerebral aqueduct), resulting in disparate dilation of ventricles upstream versus downstream of the lesion.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Structural Blockage] --> B[CSF Accumulation Upstream]; B --> C[Ventricular Dilation]; C --> D[Increased ICP]; D --> E[Brain Compression];

content.definition: Subacute Combined Degeneration (SCD) is a progressive degeneration of the spinal cord caused by [[vitamin_b12_deficiency]], characterized by the demyelination of the dorsal columns, lateral corticospinal tracts, and spinocerebellar tracts.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to accumulation of methylmalonic acid, which impairs myelin synthesis, causing vacuolar degeneration of spinal tracts.
  • Affected Tracts:
    1. Dorsal Columns: Loss of proprioception/vibration (sensory ataxia, +Romberg).
    2. Lateral Corticospinal: Spastic paresis, hyperreflexia, +Babinski (Upper Motor Neuron signs).
    3. Spinocerebellar: Ataxia.
  • Clinical Presentation: Paresthesias, gait ataxia, weakness, and eventual spastic paralysis.
  • Associations: Pernicious anemia, gastric bypass, vegan diet, diphyllobothrium latum infection.
  • USMLE Tip: "Combined" refers to the combination of Sensory (Dorsal column) and Motor (Corticospinal) deficits. Always check B12 in patients with neuropathy/ataxia.
content.takeAway: Subacute Combined Degeneration is the classic neurological manifestation of B12 deficiency, presenting as a unique mix of UMN signs (spasticity) and loss of proprioception/vibration due to specific white matter tract demyelination.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Vitamin B12 Deficiency] --> B[Elevated Methylmalonic Acid]; B --> C[Abnormal Myelin Synthesis]; C --> D[Demyelination]; D --> E[Dorsal Column Loss]; D --> F[Corticospinal Tract Loss];

content.definition: The Abducens Nerve (CN VI) is a purely motor cranial nerve that originates from the pons and innervates the ipsilateral [[lateral_rectus]] muscle, responsible for abducting the eye (moving it laterally).
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Abducens nucleus in the dorsal pons (facial nerve fibers loop around it).
  • Course: Exits at the pontomedullary junction, travels through the cavernous sinus (most susceptible to injury here), and enters the orbit via the superior orbital fissure.
  • Function: Motor innervation of the Lateral Rectus.
  • Clinical: Lesion causes medial strabismus (eye turns in) and horizontal diplopia that worsens when looking toward the affected side.
  • USMLE Tip: Because of its long intracranial course, CN VI is highly susceptible to stretching from elevated intracranial pressure (causing a "false localizing sign").
content.takeAway: The Abducens Nerve is the sole innovator of the lateral rectus muscle; its palsy results in the inability to look laterally and is a common sign of raised intracranial pressure due to its long, vulnerable path.

content.definition: Abnormal motor posturing refers to involuntary, reflexive flexion or extension of the limbs in comatose patients, indicating severe brain injury and serving as a clinical marker for the level of brainstem damage (above or below the red nucleus).
content.atAGlance:
• Decorticate (Flexor): Arms flexed/adducted (hands like 'C's moving toward the 'Cord'), legs extended. Indicates lesion above the [[red_nucleus]] (e.g., cerebral hemispheres, internal capsule).
  • Decerebrate (Extensor): Arms extended/pronated, legs extended. Indicates lesion at or below the [[red_nucleus]] (e.g., midbrain, upper pons).
  • Prognosis: Decerebrate posturing generally indicates more severe brainstem damage and a worse prognosis than decorticate.
  • Pathophysiology: Disinhibition of the [[rubrospinal_tract]] (flexion) vs. dominance of the [[vestibulospinal_tract]] (extension).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember: Decorticate = Hands near the Cor (Heart).
content.takeAway: Abnormal motor posturing distinguishes the level of brain injury: Decorticate (flexor) implies hemispheric damage sparing the red nucleus, while Decerebrate (extensor) implies deeper brainstem damage affecting the red nucleus.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Brain Injury] --> B{Lesion Location?}; B -->|Above Red Nucleus| C[Decorticate Posturing]; B -->|At/Below Red Nucleus| D[Decerebrate Posturing]; C --> E[Flexor Tone Dominates]; D --> F[Extensor Tone Dominates];

content.definition: Absence seizures (formerly petit mal) are a type of generalized seizure primarily affecting children, characterized by sudden, brief lapses of consciousness ("staring spells") without loss of postural tone or postictal confusion, associated with a distinct 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG pattern.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Presentation: Sudden behavioral arrest (staring), eyelid fluttering, or automatisms (lip smacking); lasts ~10 seconds; immediate return to baseline (no postictal state).
  • Triggers: Often provoked by hyperventilation.
  • EEG: Classic generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges.
  • Treatment: First-line is [[ethosuximide]] (blocks T-type Ca2+ channels); [[valproate]] is second-line (especially if co-occurring tonic-clonic seizures).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[focal_impaired_awareness_seizure]] (complex partial) which does have a postictal state and lasts longer.
content.takeAway: Absence seizures are pediatric generalized seizures defined by brief staring spells and a pathognomonic 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG, uniquely treated with [[ethosuximide]].
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Thalamocortical Circuitry] --> B[Abnormal Oscillation]; B --> C[3 Hz Spike-and-Wave]; C --> D[Brief Loss of Awareness]; D --> E[No Postictal Confusion];

content.definition: Ethosuximide is a narrow-spectrum anticonvulsant that acts by blocking T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons, specifically indicated for the treatment of [[absence_seizure]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Blocks voltage-gated T-type Ca2+ channels in the [[thalamus]], disrupting the thalamocortical oscillations responsible for absence seizures.
  • Clinical Use: First-line monotherapy for [[absence_seizure]].
  • Adverse Effects: GI distress (nausea/vomiting), fatigue, headache, itching, and rarely [[stevens_johnson_syndrome]].
  • USMLE Tip: Remember "Ethosuximide for Everyone's Favorite Generalized Heart-throb" (EFGH: Ethosuximide, Fatigue, GI distress, Headache). Or simply: It SUCKS (Ethosuximide) to have Silent Seizures.
content.takeAway: Ethosuximide is the drug of choice for [[absence_seizure]] because it specifically targets the T-type calcium channels in the thalamus that generate the characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave rhythm.

content.definition: Acalculia is an acquired neurological deficit characterized by the inability to perform simple mathematical calculations, classically associated with lesions to the dominant parietal lobe (specifically the angular gyrus).
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Dominant (usually Left) [[parietal_lobe]] (Angular Gyrus).
  • Associations: A core component of [[gerstmann_syndrome]] (along with agraphia, finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation).
  • Etiology: Stroke (e.g., [[middle_cerebral_artery]] infarct), tumor, or neurodegeneration.
  • USMLE Tip: If a patient cannot subtract 7 from 100 serially and has right-left confusion, suspect a dominant parietal lesion.
content.takeAway: Acalculia is a localizing sign for dominant parietal lobe dysfunction, most famously as part of the tetrad of [[gerstmann_syndrome]].

content.definition: The Accessory Nerve (CN XI) is a purely motor cranial nerve that originates from the upper cervical spinal cord, enters the skull via the foramen magnum, and exits via the [[jugular_foramen]] to innervate the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and trapezius muscles.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Head turning (SCM) and shoulder shrugging (Trapezius).
  • Course: Spinal roots C1-C5 → Foramen Magnum → Jugular Foramen → Muscles.
  • Lesion Findings:
    - LMN Lesion: Ipsilateral shoulder droop (weak trapezius), difficulty turning head to the contralateral side (weak ipsilateral SCM).
    - Winged Scapula: Can occur (lateral winging) but distinct from Long Thoracic Nerve injury (medial winging).
  • USMLE Tip: To test the Right SCM, the patient turns their head to the Left. A Right CN XI lesion causes weakness turning head to the Left.
content.takeAway: CN XI is unique for its spinal origin and cranial exit; damage results in ipsilateral shoulder weakness and difficulty turning the head away from the lesion.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[C1-C5 Spinal Roots] --> B[Foramen Magnum]; B --> C[Jugular Foramen]; C --> D[Sternocleidomastoid]; C --> E[Trapezius];

content.definition: The Accommodation Reflex is the visual response to focusing on a near object, characterized by the triad of convergence, miosis (pupillary constriction), and lens thickening (accommodation), mediated by the parasympathetic fibers of [[oculomotor_nerve]].
content.atAGlance:
• Triad:
    1. Convergence: Medial recti contraction (CN III).
    2. Miosis: Sphincter pupillae contraction (CN III parasympathetics) to increase depth of field.
    3. Accommodation: Ciliary muscle contraction → Zonules relax → Lens rounds up (increases refractive power).
  • Pathway: Retina → Optic Nerve → LGN → Visual Cortex → Superior Colliculus/Pretectum → Edinger-Westphal Nucleus → Ciliary Ganglion → Eye.
  • Clinical Relevance: Argyll Robertson Pupil (Neurosyphilis) shows "Light-Near Dissociation" (pupils accommodate but do not react to light).
  • USMLE Tip: Ciliary muscle contraction leads to zonule relaxation. This is counterintuitive but critical.
content.takeAway: Accommodation allows for near vision through a coordinated parasympathetic response that rounds the lens, constricts the pupil, and converges the eyes; this reflex can be spared in pathways affecting the light reflex (Light-Near Dissociation).
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Visual Cortex] --> B[Edinger-Westphal Nucleus]; B -->|CN III Parasympathetic| C[Ciliary Ganglion]; C --> D[Sphincter Pupillae (Miosis)]; C --> E[Ciliary Muscle (Lens Rounding)];

content.definition: Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts primarily in the proximal convoluted tubule of the kidney to inhibit HCO3- reabsorption, causing a metabolic acidosis and diuresis, while also reducing aqueous humor and CSF production.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Inhibits carbonic anhydrase → Decreased H+ secretion → Increased Na+/K+/HCO3- excretion.
  • Clinical Uses: [[glaucoma]] (decreases aqueous humor), [[idiopathic_intracranial_hypertension]] (decreases CSF), [[altitude_sickness]] (metabolic acidosis stimulates respiration), metabolic alkalosis.
  • Adverse Effects: Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis (Type 2), paresthesias, NH3 toxicity, sulfa allergy, hypokalemia, kidney stones (calcium phosphate).
  • USMLE Tip: "ACID-azolamide" causes Acidosis. Useful for alkalinizing urine (e.g., to excrete uric acid/cystine) but contraindicated in cirrhosis (traps ammonia).
content.takeAway: Acetazolamide is a diuretic that uniquely causes metabolic acidosis by dumping bicarbonate, making it useful for altitude sickness and glaucoma, but risking Type 2 RTA.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Acetazolamide] --|Inhibits| B[Carbonic Anhydrase]; B --> C[Decreased H+ Formation]; C --> D[Decreased Na+/H+ Exchange]; D --> E[Increased HCO3- Excretion]; E --> F[Metabolic Acidosis];

content.definition: Acetylcholine (ACh) is a major neurotransmitter synthesized from choline and acetyl-CoA that acts on nicotinic (ligand-gated ion channels) and muscarinic (G-protein coupled) receptors to mediate motor control, autonomic functions, and cognition.
content.atAGlance:
• Sites of Action:
    1. NMJ: Somatic motor neurons (Nicotinic).
    2. Autonomic Ganglia: Both Sympathetic and Parasympathetic (Nicotinic).
    3. Parasympathetic Effectors: Smooth muscle, glands, heart (Muscarinic).
    4. CNS: Basal nucleus of Meynert (Cognition/Memory).
  • Synthesis/Degradation: Made by Choline Acetyltransferase (ChAT); degraded by [[acetylcholinesterase]] (AChE).
  • Pathology: Decreased in [[alzheimer_disease]] and [[huntington_disease]]; Increased in [[parkinson_disease]] (relative to dopamine).
  • USMLE Tip: In the Sympathetic NS, ACh is the neurotransmitter at the ganglion AND at the Sweat Glands (muscarinic) and Adrenal Medulla (nicotinic).
content.takeAway: Acetylcholine is the primary neurotransmitter of the parasympathetic nervous system and the neuromuscular junction; its levels are critically reduced in [[alzheimer_disease]] and targeted by AChE inhibitors.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Choline + Acetyl-CoA] -->|ChAT| B[Acetylcholine]; B -->|Release| C[Synaptic Cleft]; C -->|AChE| D[Choline + Acetate]; C --> E[Nicotinic/Muscarinic Receptors];

content.definition: The Achilles Reflex (Ankle Jerk) is a deep tendon reflex mediated by the S1 and S2 nerve roots (primarily S1), where striking the Achilles tendon causes plantar flexion of the foot.
content.atAGlance:
• Nerve Roots: S1, S2.
  • Nerve: [[tibial_nerve]].
  • Action: Plantar flexion of the foot via the gastrocnemius/soleus muscles.
  • Clinical Significance:
    - Decreased/Absent: S1 radiculopathy (e.g., herniated disc), peripheral neuropathy (e.g., diabetes), [[guillain_barre_syndrome]].
    - Delayed Relaxation: Classic sign of [[hypothyroidism]].
  • USMLE Tip: Mnemonic: "S1, S2, buckle my shoe" (Achilles reflex).
content.takeAway: The Achilles Reflex primarily tests the integrity of the S1 nerve root and the tibial nerve; loss suggests pathology at this level or peripheral neuropathy.

content.definition: An Action Potential is a rapid, transient, and regenerative change in membrane potential that propagates along an excitable membrane (neuron or muscle), driven by the sequential opening and closing of voltage-gated sodium and potassium channels.
content.atAGlance:
• Phases:
    0. Depolarization: Voltage-gated Na+ channels open (Na+ influx).
    1. Repolarization: Na+ channels inactivate, Voltage-gated K+ channels open (K+ efflux).
    2. Hyperpolarization: K+ channels remain open, membrane potential dips below resting.
  • Threshold: All-or-none principle (usually -55 mV).
  • Refractory Periods:
    - Absolute: Na+ channels inactivated (no new AP possible).
    - Relative: Na+ channels reset but K+ efflux continues (requires stronger stimulus).
  • USMLE Tip: [[tetrodotoxin]] (Pufferfish) blocks Na+ channels (prevents depolarization). [[tetraethylammonium]] blocks K+ channels (prolongs repolarization).
content.takeAway: The Action Potential is the fundamental unit of neural communication, driven by Na+ influx (depolarization) followed by K+ efflux (repolarization), a sequence targeted by numerous toxins and anesthetics.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Resting Potential] -->|Stimulus| B[Threshold Reached]; B -->|Na+ Channels Open| C[Depolarization]; C -->|Na+ Inactivate / K+ Open| D[Repolarization]; D -->|K+ Slow Close| E[Hyperpolarization]; E -->|Na+/K+ Pump| A;

content.definition: Acute Disseminated Encephalomyelitis (ADEM) is an acute, monophasic inflammatory demyelinating disorder of the CNS that typically occurs following a viral infection or vaccination, characterized by multifocal neurologic deficits and altered mental status.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Molecular mimicry leads to autoimmune demyelination.
  • Clinical Presentation: Rapid onset of multifocal deficits (e.g., ataxia, weakness, vision loss) + Encephalopathy (confusion/coma) occurring 1-2 weeks post-infection (e.g., Measles, VZV) or vaccination.
  • Imaging: MRI shows multiple, asymmetric, hyperintense white matter lesions.
  • Differentiation: Unlike [[multiple_sclerosis]], ADEM is typically monophasic (one-time event) and involves encephalopathy.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a child with neurologic symptoms weeks after a viral illness or vaccine (e.g., Rabies vaccine).
content.takeAway: ADEM is a post-infectious autoimmune attack on CNS myelin, distinguished from MS by its monophasic course and the presence of altered mental status (encephalopathy).

content.definition: Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) is the most common subtype of [[guillain_barre_syndrome]], characterized by an acute, ascending, symmetrical autoimmune demyelination of peripheral nerves and roots, often triggered by a preceding infection.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Molecular mimicry (e.g., anti-ganglioside antibodies) following infection (classically [[campylobacter_jejuni]], Zika, CMV) leads to immune attack on Schwann cells/myelin.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symmetric ascending muscle weakness/paralysis, absent deep tendon reflexes (areflexia), and potential autonomic dysregulation or respiratory failure.
  • Diagnosis: CSF shows albuminocytologic dissociation (high protein, normal WBC). Nerve conduction studies show slowed conduction (demyelination).
  • Treatment: IVIG or Plasmapheresis. Steroids are NOT effective.
  • USMLE Tip: "Ascending paralysis" after bloody diarrhea ([[campylobacter_jejuni]]) is the classic vignette. Watch for respiratory failure (measure Vital Capacity).
content.takeAway: AIDP is the classic form of Guillain-Barré, presenting as an ascending paralysis with areflexia and albuminocytologic dissociation, requiring urgent monitoring for respiratory compromise.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Infection e.g. Campylobacter] --> B[Antibody Production]; B --> C[Cross-reactivity with Gangliosides]; C --> D[Attack on Schwann Cells]; D --> E[Peripheral Demyelination]; E --> F[Ascending Paralysis];

content.definition: The Adenohypophysis is the glandular anterior lobe of the [[pituitary_gland]], derived from oral ectoderm ([[rathke_pouch]]), which synthesizes and secretes six major hormones in response to hypothalamic releasing factors delivered via the hypophyseal portal system.
content.atAGlance:
• Embryology: Derived from Rathke's Pouch (surface ectoderm), unlike the neurohypophysis (neuroectoderm).
  • Hormones (FLAT PiG): FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH (Basophils); Prolactin, GH (Acidophils).
  • Regulation: Controlled by the [[hypothalamus]] via the hypophyseal portal system (blood), not direct neural connection.
  • Pathology: [[pituitary_adenoma]] (e.g., Prolactinoma), [[sheehan_syndrome]] (ischemic necrosis post-partum), [[craniopharyngioma]] (Rathke's pouch remnant).
  • USMLE Tip: Acidophils (GH, Prolactin) stain pink; Basophils (FSH, LH, ACTH, TSH) stain blue. "B-FLAT".
content.takeAway: The Adenohypophysis is the master glandular center derived from oral ectoderm, regulating growth, metabolism, and reproduction through the secretion of tropic hormones under hypothalamic vascular control.

content.definition: Adenovirus is a non-enveloped, double-stranded linear DNA virus responsible for a wide range of clinical syndromes, most notably pharyngoconjunctival fever, pneumonia, and hemorrhagic cystitis.
content.atAGlance:
• Transmission: Respiratory droplets, fecal-oral, direct contact (fomites). Highly stable in the environment.
  • Clinical Syndromes:
    - Pharyngoconjunctival Fever: Fever + Sore throat + [[conjunctivitis]] ("Pink eye").
    - Pneumonia: Especially in military recruits (vaccine available for military).
    - Hemorrhagic Cystitis: Hematuria and dysuria in children.
    - Gastroenteritis: Watery diarrhea.
  • Histology: Intranuclear inclusions.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a child with "Pink eye" after swimming (swimming pool conjunctivitis) or a military recruit with pneumonia.
content.takeAway: Adenovirus is a hardy DNA virus that causes outbreaks of conjunctivitis, respiratory illness (military recruits), and hemorrhagic cystitis in children.

content.definition: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive peroxisomal disorder caused by a mutation in the ABCD1 gene, leading to impaired beta-oxidation of very-long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs), which accumulate in and damage the adrenal glands and CNS myelin.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Defective transport of VLCFAs into peroxisomes → Accumulation of VLCFAs → Toxicity to adrenal cortex and white matter.
  • Clinical Presentation: Progressive neurologic deterioration (dementia, vision loss, ataxia) + [[adrenal_insufficiency]] (skin hyperpigmentation, hypotension) in young boys.
  • Genetics: X-linked recessive.
  • Diagnosis: Elevated VLCFAs in plasma.
  • USMLE Tip: Think of this when a young boy presents with behavioral changes/school failure AND signs of Addison disease (tan skin, low Na, high K).
content.takeAway: Adrenoleukodystrophy is a peroxisomal disease of VLCFA accumulation that uniquely combines progressive CNS demyelination with primary adrenal insufficiency.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[ABCD1 Mutation] --> B[Impaired Peroxisomal Entry]; B --> C[Accumulation of VLCFAs]; C --> D[Adrenal Gland Damage]; C --> E[CNS Demyelination]; D --> F[Adrenal Insufficiency]; E --> G[Neurologic Deterioration];

content.definition: Age-Related Macular Degeneration (AMD) is the leading cause of irreversible central vision loss in the elderly, characterized by the degeneration of the macula due to oxidative stress and the accumulation of extracellular deposits called drusen.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - Dry (Non-exudative): Gradual vision loss; characterized by subretinal drusen (yellow deposits) and pigmentary changes. Most common (85%).
    - Wet (Exudative): Rapid vision loss; characterized by choroidal neovascularization (VEGF-driven) leading to bleeding/leakage.
  • Clinical: Central scotoma (loss of central vision), metamorphopsia (distortion of straight lines).
  • Treatment:
    - Dry: Antioxidant vitamins (AREDS), smoking cessation.
    - Wet: Anti-VEGF injections (e.g., [[ranibizumab]], [[bevacizumab]]).
  • USMLE Tip: "Metamorphopsia" (wavy lines on Amsler grid) suggests Wet AMD. Peripheral vision is preserved (unlike [[glaucoma]]).
content.takeAway: AMD destroys central vision (macula) while sparing peripheral vision; Dry AMD involves drusen, while Wet AMD involves neovascularization treatable with anti-VEGF therapy.

content.definition: Agraphia is an acquired neurological deficit characterized by the inability to write or communicate through writing, often resulting from lesions in the dominant parietal lobe or frontal lobe language centers.
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Dominant [[parietal_lobe]] (Angular Gyrus) or Frontal Lobe (Exner's area).
  • Associations: A core component of [[gerstmann_syndrome]] (Agraphia + Acalculia + Finger Agnosia + Left-Right Disorientation).
  • Context: Can occur in isolation or with aphasia (e.g., [[broca_aphasia]] patients have agraphia matching their speech deficits).
  • USMLE Tip: Agraphia without aphasia points strongly to the dominant angular gyrus (Gerstmann Syndrome).
content.takeAway: Agraphia is the loss of writing ability, serving as a key localizing sign for dominant parietal lobe pathology, particularly when grouped with the other elements of [[gerstmann_syndrome]].

content.definition: Akathisia is an extrapyramidal symptom characterized by a subjective feeling of inner restlessness and an objective inability to sit still (e.g., pacing, tapping feet), most commonly caused by [[antipsychotics]] blocking dopamine receptors.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: High-potency typical [[antipsychotics]] (e.g., [[haloperidol]]) or antiemetics (e.g., [[metoclopramide]]).
  • Timeline: Days to weeks after starting medication.
  • Differentiation: Often mistaken for worsening agitation/psychosis (leading to increased drug dose, worsening the akathisia).
  • Treatment: Decrease dose, switch to atypical, or treat with Beta-blockers ([[propranolol]]) or Benzodiazepines. Benztropine is less effective here than for dystonia.
  • USMLE Tip: Patient on Haloperidol feels "jumping out of their skin" and keeps pacing the room. Treat with Propranolol.
content.takeAway: Akathisia is a drug-induced motor restlessness often misdiagnosed as anxiety; unlike other EPS, it responds best to beta-blockers ([[propranolol]]) rather than anticholinergics.

content.definition: The Edinger-Westphal Nucleus is the visceral accessory nucleus of the [[oculomotor_nerve]] located in the midbrain, serving as the source of preganglionic parasympathetic fibers that control pupillary constriction and lens accommodation.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Dorsal Midbrain, rostral to the Oculomotor Nucleus.
  • Input: Pretectal nuclei (Light Reflex), Visual Cortex (Accommodation).
  • Output: Preganglionic parasympathetic fibers travel with CN III → [[ciliary_ganglion]].
  • Function: Innervates Sphincter Pupillae (Miosis) and Ciliary Muscle (Accommodation).
  • Clinical Relevance: Damage results in a dilated, fixed pupil (loss of parasympathetic tone).
  • USMLE Tip: In [[argyll_robertson_pupil]] (Neurosyphilis), the pretectal input is damaged (no light reflex), but cortical input remains (accommodation intact).
content.takeAway: The Edinger-Westphal Nucleus provides the parasympathetic drive for the eye; its fibers run superficially on CN III, making them vulnerable to compression (e.g., PCom aneurysm).
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Light Stimulus] --> B[Pretectal Nucleus]; B -->|Bilateral Projection| C[Edinger-Westphal Nucleus]; C -->|CN III| D[Ciliary Ganglion]; D -->|Short Ciliary Nerves| E[Sphincter Pupillae];

content.definition: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS) is a heterogeneous group of connective tissue disorders caused by defects in collagen synthesis or processing, characterized by tissue fragility, skin hyperextensibility, and joint hypermobility.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Mutations in Collagen (Type III or V) or processing enzymes (e.g., procollagen peptidase).
  • Clinical Features: Stretchy skin, easy bruising, joint dislocations, poor wound healing ("cigarette paper" scars).
  • Vascular Type (Type IV): Mutation in Type III Collagen (COL3A1). Risk of [[saccular_aneurysm]], organ rupture (uterus, bowel), and [[aortic_dissection]].
  • Classic Type: Mutation in Type V Collagen (COL5A1/2). Skin/Joint symptoms predominant.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[marfan_syndrome]]: Marfan has tall stature/lens dislocation (Fibrillin); EDS has stretchy skin/easy bruising (Collagen).
content.takeAway: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome involves defective collagen, leading to structural weakness; the Vascular type is particularly dangerous due to the risk of spontaneous [[saccular_aneurysm]] rupture.

content.definition: Embolic Stroke is a type of ischemic stroke caused by a blood clot or debris traveling from a distant site (usually the heart or carotids) and lodging in a cerebral artery, typically characterized by sudden onset of maximal deficits.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiologies:
    - Cardiac: [[atrial_fibrillation]], mural thrombus (post-MI), infective endocarditis (septic emboli), [[patent_foramen_ovale]] (paradoxical embolus).
    - Arterial: Carotid plaque rupture.
  • Territory: Often affects multiple vascular territories or the [[middle_cerebral_artery]] (largest target).
  • Imaging: CT may show wedge-shaped infarcts at the gray-white junction (cortical).
  • Clinical: Abrupt onset symptoms (unlike thrombotic, which may stutter).
  • USMLE Tip: A patient with "sudden onset" aphasia and a history of "palpitations" (A-fib) likely has an embolic stroke.
content.takeAway: Embolic Strokes are acute ischemic events originating largely from cardiac sources (like A-fib), producing sudden, often cortical, neurologic deficits.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Atrial Fibrillation] --> B[Left Atrial Thrombus]; B --> C[Embolization to Brain]; C --> D[Occlusion of MCA]; D --> E[Cortical Ischemia/Stroke];

content.definition: The Emboliform Nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei (part of the Interposed Nuclei along with the Globose) involved in the coordination of limb movements via the spinocerebellar pathway.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Deep white matter of the cerebellum.
  • Functional Group: Interposed Nuclei (Emboliform + Globose).
  • Input: Paravermis (Spinocerebellum).
  • Output: Contralateral Red Nucleus (via Superior Cerebellar Peduncle) to influence the Rubrospinal tract.
  • Function: Adjusts limb movements and muscle tone.
  • Mnemonic: "Don't Eat Greasy Foods" (Lateral to Medial: Dentate, Emboliform, Globose, Fastigial).
content.takeAway: The Emboliform Nucleus works with the Globose nucleus to regulate limb motor execution, projecting primarily to the red nucleus.

content.definition: Encephalotrigeminal Angiomatosis, commonly known as [[sturge_weber_syndrome]], is a congenital neurocutaneous disorder caused by a somatic mosaic mutation in GNAQ, characterized by a facial port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angiomas, and glaucoma.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Somatic mosaicism of activating mutation in GNAQ gene (Neural crest derivative defect). Not hereditary.
  • Clinical Triad:
    1. Port-Wine Stain (Nevus Flammeus): V1/V2 trigeminal distribution (face).
    2. Leptomeningeal Angioma: Ipsilateral vascular malformation → Seizures, Intellectual Disability.
    3. Glaucoma: Episcleral hemangioma increases IOP.
  • Imaging: "Tram-track" calcifications (calcified gyri) on skull X-ray/CT.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a child with a large facial birthmark and new-onset seizures.
content.takeAway: Encephalotrigeminal Angiomatosis (Sturge-Weber) links a facial vascular nevus with ipsilateral brain angiomas (causing seizures/calcifications) due to a somatic GNAQ mutation.

content.definition: Endolymphatic Hydrops is the distension of the endolymphatic compartment of the inner ear due to excess fluid accumulation, serving as the underlying pathologic mechanism of [[meniere_disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Impaired resorption of endolymph (via endolymphatic sac) → Increased pressure → Distortion/Rupture of membranous labyrinth.
  • Clinical Presentation (Meniere's): Episodic Vertigo, fluctuating Hearing Loss (sensorineural), Tinnitus, and aural fullness.
  • Treatment: Low salt diet, Diuretics (e.g., [[acetazolamide]], HCTZ) to reduce fluid pressure.
  • USMLE Tip: "Hydrops" = Water/Fluid. Meniere's is "glaucoma of the ear."
content.takeAway: Endolymphatic Hydrops causes the classic triad of Ménière disease (vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss) via pressure-induced dysfunction of the cochlear and vestibular hair cells.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Decreased Resorption] --> B[Accumulation of Endolymph]; B --> C[Distension of Labyrinth]; C --> D[Hair Cell Dysfunction]; D --> E[Vertigo / Hearing Loss];

content.definition: The Endoneurium is the delicate layer of loose connective tissue that surrounds individual nerve fibers (axons and their myelin sheaths) within a peripheral nerve.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Innermost layer, wrapping single axons. (Endo = Inside).
  • Structure: Collagen fibers and endoneurial fluid.
  • Pathology: Site of inflammatory infiltration in [[guillain_barre_syndrome]] (Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy).
  • Hierarchy: Endoneurium (fiber) < Perineurium (fascicle, blood-nerve barrier) < Epineurium (entire nerve).
  • USMLE Tip: Guillain-Barré inflammation is endoneurial.
content.takeAway: The Endoneurium is the deepest nerve sheath, surrounding individual axons, and is the specific site of autoimmune attack in Guillain-Barré syndrome.

content.definition: Entacapone is a peripheral COMT inhibitor (Catechol-O-methyltransferase) used as an adjunct to [[carbidopa_levodopa]] in Parkinson's disease to prolong the half-life of Levodopa.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Inhibits peripheral COMT → Prevents degradation of L-DOPA to 3-O-methyldopa (3-OMD) → Increases L-DOPA availability to cross the BBB.
  • Permeability: Does NOT cross the BBB (unlike [[tolcapone]]).
  • Clinical Use: [[parkinson_disease]] (specifically to reduce "wearing-off" effects of Levodopa).
  • Adverse Effects: Enhances L-DOPA toxicity (dyskinesia, nausea), orange discoloration of urine. No hepatotoxicity (unlike Tolcapone).
  • USMLE Tip: Entacapone enters only the Enteric system (Peripheral). Tolcapone takes a Toll on the liver (Central + Peripheral).
content.takeAway: Entacapone extends the duration of Levodopa action by inhibiting its peripheral breakdown, useful for motor fluctuations in Parkinson's without the liver toxicity of Tolcapone.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Levodopa] -->|COMT| B[3-OMD (Inactive)]; A -->|BBB| C[CNS Levodopa]; D[Entacapone] --x|Inhibits| A; A -->|Increased| C;

content.definition: The Entorhinal Cortex is a region of the medial temporal lobe that functions as the main interface between the hippocampus and the neocortex, playing a critical role in memory and spatial navigation.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Medial Temporal Lobe (part of the Parahippocampal gyrus).
  • Function: Gateway for information entering and leaving the [[hippocampus]].
  • Pathology: One of the first sites affected in [[alzheimer_disease]] (neurofibrillary tangles appear here early).
  • USMLE Tip: Damage here disconnects the hippocampus from the cortex, causing profound anterograde [[amnesia]].
content.takeAway: The Entorhinal Cortex is the bridge to the hippocampus for memory formation and is the site of earliest pathology in Alzheimer's Disease.

content.definition: Ependymal Cells are ciliated glial cells that line the [[ventricular_system]] of the brain and the central canal of the spinal cord, involved in the production and circulation of [[cerebrospinal_fluid]].
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Simple columnar/cuboidal epithelium with cilia (move CSF) and microvilli (absorb CSF).
  • Specialization: Modified ependymal cells + capillaries form the [[choroid_plexus]], which produces CSF.
  • Barrier: Form a barrier between CSF and interstitial fluid (though leaky compared to BBB).
  • Pathology: Source of [[ependymoma]]. Viral inclusions (e.g., CMV) can be found here.
content.takeAway: Ependymal Cells line the CNS fluid spaces, facilitating CSF flow via cilia and forming the secretory choroid plexus.

content.definition: Ependymoma is a malignant glial tumor derived from [[ependymal_cells]], most commonly occurring in the 4th ventricle in children, where it causes obstructive hydrocephalus.
content.atAGlance:
• Location:
    - Children: Intracranial, 4th Ventricle (Posterior Fossa).
    - Adults: Spinal cord (Cauda equina).
  • Pathology: Perivascular Pseudorosettes (tumor cells arranged around a blood vessel) and Ependymal Rosettes. Rod-shaped blepharoplasts (basal ciliary bodies).
  • Clinical: [[noncommunicating_hydrocephalus]] (headache, papilledema) due to 4th ventricle compression.
  • Prognosis: Poor (difficult to resect completely from ventricle floor).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from [[medulloblastoma]] (also 4th ventricle in kids). Ependymoma has "Rosettes" and originates from the lining of the ventricle.
content.takeAway: Ependymomas are pediatric posterior fossa tumors arising from the ventricular lining, characterized histologically by perivascular pseudorosettes and clinically by hydrocephalus.

content.definition: Epidural Hematoma is a collection of arterial blood between the skull and the [[dura_mater]], typically caused by traumatic rupture of the middle meningeal artery (MMA) at the pterion.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Fracture of the temporal bone (pterion) lacerates the high-pressure Middle Meningeal Artery. Blood strips the dura from the skull.
  • Clinical Presentation: Trauma → Loss of consciousness → Lucid Interval (feels fine) → Rapid deterioration (coma) due to expanding mass.
  • Complications: [[uncal_herniation]] (CN III palsy: down/out pupil).
  • Imaging: CT shows a Biconvex (Lentiform) hyperdensity that does not cross suture lines (dura is tethered at sutures).
  • USMLE Tip: "Talk and Die" syndrome. Lens-shaped bleed bounded by sutures.
content.takeAway: Epidural Hematoma is a life-threatening arterial bleed (MMA) defined by a biconvex shape on CT and a classic lucid interval, requiring emergent decompression.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Temporal Bone Fracture] --> B[MMA Rupture]; B --> C[Arterial Bleed]; C --> D[Epidural Space Expansion]; D --> E[Mass Effect/Herniation];

content.definition: The Epidural Space is the anatomical compartment located between the dura mater and the vertebral wall (in the spine) or the skull (in the cranium), containing fat and the internal vertebral venous plexus.
content.atAGlance:
• Spinal Epidural Space: A real space containing fat and veins. Target for Epidural Anesthesia (needle passes through Ligamentum Flavum to reach it).
  • Cranial Epidural Space: A potential space between the skull and the periosteal layer of the dura. Site of [[epidural_hematoma]] (Middle Meningeal Artery rupture).
  • Clinical Relevance:
    - Anesthesia: Injection of local anesthetics/opioids.
    - Hemorrhage: Arterial bleed creates a biconvex mass.
    - Abscess: Spinal epidural abscess.
  • USMLE Tip: During a lumbar puncture, the needle passes through the Ligamentum Flavum before entering the Epidural Space (often stopping there for epidural, or continuing through Dura for spinal tap).
content.takeAway: The Epidural Space is a real fat-filled space in the spine used for anesthesia, but a potential space in the cranium where arterial hematomas form.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Skin] --> B[Supraspinous Ligament]; B --> C[Interspinous Ligament]; C --> D[Ligamentum Flavum]; D --> E[Epidural Space]; E --> F[Dura Mater]; F --> G[Subarachnoid Space];

content.definition: Epilepsy is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by a predisposition to generate recurrent, unprovoked seizures due to abnormal, excessive, or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.
content.atAGlance:
• Diagnosis: At least two unprovoked seizures occurring >24 hours apart, or one unprovoked seizure with a high probability of recurrence (e.g., abnormal EEG).
  • Classification:
    - Focal: Originates in one hemisphere (Aware vs. Impaired Awareness).
    - Generalized: Involves both hemispheres (e.g., [[tonic_clonic_seizure]], [[absence_seizure]], [[myoclonic_seizure]]).
  • Etiologies: Genetic (e.g., [[juvenile_myoclonic_epilepsy]]), Structural (Tumor, Stroke, Mesial Temporal Sclerosis), Metabolic, Infectious.
  • Status Epilepticus: Seizure >5 min or recurrent without recovery. Treat with [[benzodiazepines]].
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from "provoked" seizures (e.g., alcohol withdrawal, hyponatremia, febrile seizures), which do not constitute epilepsy.
content.takeAway: Epilepsy is the disease of recurrent spontaneous seizures, requiring long-term management with [[anticonvulsants]] tailored to the seizure type (Focal vs. Generalized).

content.definition: Epinephrine is a direct-acting sympathomimetic catecholamine that stimulates α1, α2, β1, and β2 adrenergic receptors, used for anaphylaxis, cardiac arrest, and glaucoma.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism (Ophthalmology): Stimulates α1 (vasoconstriction) and α2 receptors in the ciliary body → Decreases aqueous humor synthesis. Also increases uveoscleral outflow.
  • Clinical Use: [[open_angle_glaucoma]] (rarely used now), Anaphylaxis (DOC), Cardiac Arrest, Croup (Racemic).
  • Adverse Effects: Mydriasis (Contraindicated in Closed-Angle Glaucoma), Hypertension, Arrhythmias, Anxiety.
  • USMLE Tip: DO NOT use in closed-angle glaucoma because mydriasis (via α1 on radial muscle) crowds the angle and worsens obstruction.
content.takeAway: Epinephrine is a potent non-selective adrenergic agonist that lowers intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous production, but its mydriatic effect makes it dangerous in closed-angle glaucoma.

content.definition: The Epineurium is the dense, irregular connective tissue layer that surrounds the entire peripheral nerve trunk, binding multiple nerve fascicles together and containing the nutrient blood vessels (vasa nervorum).
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Outermost layer of a peripheral nerve.
  • Function: Structural support, protection, and housing for blood supply.
  • Hierarchy:
    1. Epineurium: Surrounds entire nerve.
    2. [[perineurium]]: Surrounds fascicles (Blood-Nerve Barrier).
    3. [[endoneurium]]: Surrounds individual axons.
  • Clinical Relevance: Often sutured during surgical nerve repair (neurorrhaphy).
content.takeAway: The Epineurium is the tough outer sheath of a peripheral nerve, encasing fascicles wrapped in perineurium and axons wrapped in endoneurium.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Peripheral Nerve] --> B[Epineurium]; B --> C[Fascicles]; C --> D[Perineurium]; D --> E[Axons]; E --> F[Endoneurium];

content.definition: Esotropia is a form of [[strabismus]] characterized by the inward deviation (convergence) of one or both eyes ("crossed eyes"), potentially leading to amblyopia if untreated.
content.atAGlance:
• Presentation: Eye turns inward toward the nose.
  • Etiologies:
    - Congenital: Infantile esotropia.
    - Accommodative: Due to uncorrected [[hyperopia]] (farsightedness) causing excessive convergence.
    - Paralytic: [[abducens_nerve]] (CN VI) palsy (Lateral Rectus weakness).
  • Complications: [[amblyopia]] (brain suppresses image from deviating eye), loss of binocular vision/stereopsis.
  • Treatment: Glasses (for accommodative), Patching (for amblyopia), Surgery.
content.takeAway: Esotropia is inward eye deviation; in children, it requires prompt correction to prevent permanent cortical visual loss ([[amblyopia]]), while in adults, it often signals CN VI palsy.

content.definition: Essential Tremor is the most common movement disorder, characterized by a high-frequency action and postural tremor of the upper extremities (and often head/voice) that worsens with movement and anxiety.
content.atAGlance:
• Features: Action tremor (worsens when holding a posture or reaching for a target). Bilateral. Improves with Alcohol.
  • Genetics: Often familial (Autosomal Dominant).
  • Differentiation: Contrast with [[parkinson_disease]] (Resting tremor, pill-rolling, gets better with movement).
  • Treatment:
    - First-line: [[propranolol]] (Beta-blocker) or [[primidone]] (Barbiturate).
  • USMLE Tip: "Patient drinks a glass of wine and the shaking stops."
content.takeAway: Essential Tremor is a familial action tremor relieved by alcohol and beta-blockers, distinguishing it from the resting tremor of Parkinson's.

content.definition: Eszopiclone is a non-benzodiazepine sedative-hypnotic ("Z-drug") that acts as an agonist at the BZ1 subtype of the [[gaba_a_receptor]], used for the treatment of insomnia.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Binds GABAA receptor at a distinct site from benzos; selective for BZ1 subtype (sedation > anxiolysis).
  • Pharmacokinetics: Rapid onset, relatively short duration. Reversible by [[flumazenil]].
  • Clinical Use: Insomnia (difficulty falling or staying asleep).
  • Adverse Effects: Ataxia, headaches, confusion, metallic taste. Less tolerance/dependence risk than benzodiazepines.
  • USMLE Tip: "All the Zzzs put you to sleep" (Zolpidem, Zaleplon, esZopiclone).
content.takeAway: Eszopiclone is a Z-drug that induces sleep via GABAA modulation with a lower side-effect profile than benzodiazepines, reversible by flumazenil.

content.definition: Ethosuximide is a narrow-spectrum anticonvulsant that specifically blocks T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons, making it the first-line treatment for [[absence_seizure]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Blocks T-type Ca2+ channels in the [[thalamus]], disrupting the 3 Hz spike-and-wave rhythmicity.
  • Clinical Use: Absence Seizures (Petit mal) only. Ineffective for tonic-clonic or focal seizures.
  • Adverse Effects: EFGH: Ethosuximide causes Fatigue, GI distress, Headache. Rare: [[stevens_johnson_syndrome]].
  • USMLE Tip: If a patient has both absence and tonic-clonic seizures, use [[valproate]] instead (Ethosuximide won't cover the tonic-clonic).
content.takeAway: Ethosuximide targets thalamic T-type calcium channels to treat absence seizures exclusively.

content.definition: Etomidate is a short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent that potentiates [[gaba_a_receptor]] activity, favored for induction in hemodynamically unstable patients due to its minimal cardiovascular depression.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Potentiates GABAA receptors.
  • Clinical Use: Rapid Sequence Intubation (RSI), anesthesia induction.
  • Advantages: Hemodynamic stability (minimal effect on BP/HR/CO). ideal for trauma/shock patients.
  • Adverse Effects: Adrenal Suppression (inhibits 11β-hydroxylase), Postoperative nausea/vomiting, Myoclonus.
  • USMLE Tip: Use in the hypotensive trauma patient, but watch out for adrenal insufficiency.
content.takeAway: Etomidate is the induction agent of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients but carries a risk of transient adrenal suppression.

content.definition: Ex Vacuo Ventriculomegaly is the compensatory enlargement of the cerebral ventricles and subarachnoid spaces secondary to the loss of brain tissue (atrophy), rather than increased cerebrospinal fluid pressure.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Brain atrophy (neuronal loss) → Brain shrinks → CSF fills the empty space.
  • Intracranial Pressure (ICP): Normal.
  • Etiologies: [[alzheimer_disease]], [[huntington_disease]], [[frontotemporal_dementia]], HIV-associated dementia, Normal aging.
  • Imaging: Enlarged ventricles with prominent/widened sulci (cortical atrophy).
  • Differentiation: Contrast with [[normal_pressure_hydrocephalus]] (Ventricles disproportionately large compared to sulci/atrophy; triad of wet/wobbly/wacky).
content.takeAway: Ex Vacuo Ventriculomegaly is an appearance of hydrocephalus caused by brain atrophy, distinguished by normal ICP and proportionate sulcal widening.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Neurodegeneration] --> B[Cortical Atrophy]; B --> C[Loss of Brain Volume]; C --> D[Passive Expansion of Ventricles]; D --> E[Hydrocephalus Ex Vacuo];

content.definition: Broca Aphasia (Expressive Aphasia) is a non-fluent aphasia caused by a lesion in the posterior inferior frontal gyrus ([[broca_area]]), characterized by sparse, halting speech, impaired repetition, but relatively preserved comprehension.
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion: Left Inferior Frontal Gyrus.
  • Vessel: Superior division of the [[middle_cerebral_artery]].
  • Clinical: "Broken" speech (agrammatic), frustration (insight intact). Often associated with right hemiparesis (face/arm).
content.takeAway: Broca Aphasia destroys speech production ("Expressive") while sparing comprehension, localizing to the frontal lobe.

content.definition: Neonatal Extracranial Injuries are traumatic scalp swellings occurring during birth, distinguished by their anatomical location relative to the skull sutures and periosteum.
content.atAGlance:
• [[caput_succedaneum]]: Edema above periosteum. Soft/boggy. Crosses suture lines. Resolves quickly.
  • [[cephalohematoma]]: Subperiosteal blood. Firm. Bounded by suture lines. Resolves slowly; risk of jaundice.
  • [[subgaleal_hemorrhage]]: Blood under galea aponeurosis. Diffuse, fluctuant, crosses sutures. Life-threatening (can hold large volume of blood).
  • USMLE Tip: Caput Crosses. Cephalohematoma is Confined. Subgaleal is Scary.
content.takeAway: Differentiating neonatal scalp swelling relies on suture line boundaries: Caput (crosses, benign), Cephalohematoma (bounded, jaundice risk), Subgaleal (diffuse, hemorrhage risk).

content.definition: Eye Movements are coordinated by the six extraocular muscles, innervated by Cranial Nerves III, IV, and VI, and controlled by brainstem gaze centers.
content.atAGlance:
• Innervation Formula: LR6 SO4 R3 (Lateral Rectus = CN VI; Superior Oblique = CN IV; Rest = CN III).
  • Actions:
    - Lateral Rectus: Abduction.
    - Medial Rectus: Adduction.
    - Superior Oblique: Intorsion, Depression.
    - Inferior Oblique: Extorsion, Elevation.
    - Superior Rectus: Elevation.
    - Inferior Rectus: Depression.
  • Gaze Centers:
    - Horizontal: [[paramedian_pontine_reticular_formation]] (PPRF).
    - Vertical: Rostral interstitial nucleus of MLF (Midbrain).
  • Pathology: Palsies (CN III down/out; CN IV vertical diplopia/head tilt; CN VI medial deviation).
content.takeAway: Eye Movements depend on the precise coordination of CN III, IV, and VI; dysfunction leads to specific patterns of diplopia and strabismus.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[CN VI] --> B[Lateral Rectus (Abduct)]; C[CN IV] --> D[Superior Oblique (Intort/Depress)]; E[CN III] --> F[Medial/Sup/Inf Recti + Inf Oblique];

content.definition: Eyelid Disorders encompass inflammatory, infectious, and structural pathologies of the eyelid, including blepharitis, hordeolum, chalazion, and cellulitis.
content.atAGlance:
• [[blepharitis]]: Chronic inflammation of lid margins (crusting).
  • [[hordeolum]] (Stye): Acute, painful infection of eyelash follicle or Zeis gland (usually S. aureus).
  • [[chalazion]]: Chronic, painless lipogranuloma of Meibomian gland.
  • Preseptal Cellulitis: Infection anterior to orbital septum (mild).
  • Orbital Cellulitis: Infection posterior to septum (pain with movement, proptosis, vision loss). Emergency.
  • Ptosis: Drooping (CN III palsy, Horner's, MG).
content.takeAway: Differentiating eyelid lumps relies on pain: Hordeolum hurts, Chalazion is chill (painless). Orbital cellulitis is a vision-threatening emergency.

content.definition: The Eye is the sensory organ of vision, comprised of three layers (Fibrous, Vascular/Uvea, Neural) and refractive media (Cornea, Aqueous, Lens, Vitreous).
content.atAGlance:
• Layers:
    1. Fibrous: [[sclera]], [[cornea]].
    2. Uvea: [[choroid_layer]], [[ciliary_body]], [[iris]].
    3. Neural: [[retina]].
  • Chambers:
    - Anterior: Cornea to Iris (Aqueous).
    - Posterior: Iris to Lens (Aqueous).
    - Vitreous: Behind Lens (Vitreous humor).
  • Refraction: Cornea (2/3), Lens (1/3, adjustable).
  • Pathology: Glaucoma (Anterior chamber angle), Cataract (Lens), Macular Degeneration (Retina).
content.takeAway: The Eye is a complex optical system where the cornea and lens focus light onto the retina, maintained by the uveal tract and aqueous dynamics.

content.definition: The Facial Nerve (CN VII) is a mixed cranial nerve responsible for muscles of facial expression (branchial motor), taste to the anterior 2/3 of the tongue (special sensory), and parasympathetic innervation to the lacrimal and salivary glands.
content.atAGlance:
• Motor: Muscles of facial expression, Stapedius (dampens sound), Stylohyoid, Posterior digastric.
  • Sensory: Taste anterior 2/3 tongue (Chorda Tympani). Somatic sensation from ear canal.
  • Parasympathetic: Lacrimal glands (tearing), Submandibular/Sublingual glands (salivation).
  • Reflexes: Efferent limb of Corneal Reflex (Blink).
  • Lesions:
    - UMN (Stroke): Contralateral lower face weakness (forehead spared due to bilateral innervation).
    - LMN (Bell's Palsy): Ipsilateral hemifacial weakness (forehead involved), [[hyperacusis]], loss of taste.
content.takeAway: CN VII controls facial expression and taste; UMN lesions spare the forehead, while LMN lesions (Bell's Palsy) affect the entire hemiface.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Facial Nucleus] -->|Motor| B[Facial Muscles/Stapedius]; C[Superior Salivatory Nucleus] -->|Parasympathetic| D[Lacrimal/Salivary Glands]; E[Solitary Nucleus] -->|Sensory| F[Taste Ant 2/3 Tongue];

content.definition: Factor V Leiden is the most common inherited thrombophilia, caused by a point mutation (Arg506Gln) in Factor V that renders it resistant to cleavage and inactivation by [[protein_c]].
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Mutation makes Factor V resistant to degradation by Activated Protein C (APC). Factor V remains active → increased thrombin → hypercoagulability.
  • Genetics: Autosomal Dominant (incomplete penetrance).
  • Clinical Presentation: Recurrent Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT), Pulmonary Embolism (PE), cerebral vein thrombosis, recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Diagnosis: APC Resistance Assay, Genetic testing.
  • USMLE Tip: Most common cause of inherited hypercoagulability in Caucasians. Complications increase with OCP use.
content.takeAway: Factor V Leiden causes hypercoagulability via resistance to Activated Protein C, leading to increased risk of venous thromboembolism.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Factor V Leiden Mutation] --> B[Factor V Resistant to APC]; B --> C[Prolonged Factor V Activity]; C --> D[Increased Thrombin]; D --> E[Venous Thrombosis];

content.definition: Hyperopia (Farsightedness) is a refractive error where the eye is too short for the refractive power of the cornea and lens, causing light from near objects to focus behind the retina.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Focal point is retro-retinal. The eye is axially too short.
  • Clinical Presentation: Difficulty seeing near objects; eye strain (from constant accommodation).
  • Correction: Convex (converging) lens.
  • USMLE Tip: Compare with [[myopia]] (eye too long, focus in front, concave lens).
content.takeAway: Hyperopia results from a short globe causing light to focus behind the retina, corrected by a convex lens to increase convergence.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Light Rays] --> B[Cornea/Lens]; B --> C[Focal Point Behind Retina]; D[Convex Lens] --> B; B --> E[Focal Point On Retina];

content.definition: Fasciculations are spontaneous, involuntary muscle twitches visible under the skin, representing the contraction of a single motor unit due to the spontaneous firing of a degenerating lower motor neuron.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Hyperexcitability of sick lower motor neurons (LMN) or denervation hypersensitivity.
  • Clinical Significance: Hallmark sign of LMN injury.
  • Associations:
    - [[amyotrophic_lateral_sclerosis]] (ALS): Fasciculations + Weakness + UMN signs.
    - Spinal Muscular Atrophy.
    - [[organophosphates]] Toxicity: Acetylcholine excess.
    - Benign Fasciculation Syndrome: No weakness.
  • USMLE Tip: Tongue fasciculations are a classic sign of ALS or Bulbar Palsy.
content.takeAway: Fasciculations indicate lower motor neuron irritability or degeneration, classically seen in [[amyotrophic_lateral_sclerosis]] alongside atrophy and weakness.

content.definition: The Fastigial Nucleus is the most medial of the deep cerebellar nuclei, receiving input from the vermis and projecting to the vestibular nuclei and reticular formation to control balance, posture, and eye movements.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Medial-most deep cerebellar nucleus.
  • Input: Vermis (Spinocerebellum) and Flocculonodular lobe.
  • Output: Vestibular Nuclei and Reticular Formation via Inferior Cerebellar Peduncle.
  • Function: Axial/Truncal balance and stance.
  • Mnemonic: "Don't Eat Greasy Foods" (Lateral to Medial: Dentate, Emboliform, Globose, Fastigial). Fastigial is closest to the Fast-food (Midline/Mouth).
content.takeAway: The Fastigial Nucleus regulates medial motor systems (trunk/balance) via input from the vermis.

content.definition: A Febrile Seizure is a convulsion occurring in a child (typically 6 months to 5 years) triggered by a rapid rise in body temperature (fever) in the absence of CNS infection or metabolic imbalance.
content.atAGlance:
• Epidemiology: 6 months to 5 years. Common (2-5% of children).
  • Types:
    - Simple: Generalized tonic-clonic, <15 mins, no recurrence in 24h. Benign.
    - Complex: Focal, >15 mins, or recurrence in 24h. Slightly higher epilepsy risk.
  • Management: Reassurance and antipyretics (for comfort, doesn't prevent seizure). Workup (LP/CT) only if signs of meningitis.
  • Prognosis: Excellent. Risk of epilepsy is slightly higher than general population (~1-2% vs 1%).
  • USMLE Tip: HHV-6 (Roseola) is a classic cause of high fever and febrile seizures.
content.takeAway: Febrile Seizures are benign, fever-associated events in young children; simple cases require no workup or medication beyond reassurance.

content.definition: Fenestrated Capillaries are blood vessels with endothelial cells containing pores (fenestrae) that allow for rapid exchange of water and larger solutes, found in organs with high filtration or absorption needs.
content.atAGlance:
• Structure: Endothelial pores (fenestrae) covered by a thin diaphragm (except in kidney glomerulus).
  • Locations:
    - Kidney: Glomerulus (filtration).
    - Endocrine Glands: Pancreas, Thyroid, Pituitary (hormone secretion).
    - Intestine: Villi (absorption).
    - Choroid Plexus: CSF production.
  • USMLE Tip: Contrast with Continuous capillaries (BBB, muscle, skin) and Sinusoidal capillaries (Liver, Spleen, Bone Marrow - large gaps).
content.takeAway: Fenestrated Capillaries are porous vessels designed for high rates of exchange, crucial for renal filtration and endocrine secretion.

content.definition: Fentanyl is a potent synthetic mu-opioid receptor agonist (approx. 100x stronger than morphine) used for analgesia and anesthesia due to its rapid onset and short duration of action.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Agonist at Mu-opioid receptors → closes presynaptic Ca2+ channels / opens postsynaptic K+ channels → inhibits neurotransmission.
  • Properties: Highly lipid-soluble (rapid CNS entry). No histamine release (cardiovascular stability).
  • Clinical Use: Anesthesia adjunct, severe pain, chronic pain (transdermal patch).
  • Adverse Effects: Chest Wall Rigidity (Wooden Chest syndrome) with rapid IV bolus, Respiratory depression, Constipation.
  • USMLE Tip: The opioid of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients (no histamine/minimal hypotensive effect).
content.takeAway: Fentanyl is a highly potent, lipid-soluble opioid ideal for anesthesia and severe pain, notable for causing chest wall rigidity if pushed too fast.

content.definition: Fever is a cytokine-mediated elevation of the body's temperature set-point in the hypothalamus, typically in response to infection or inflammation.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Pyrogens (e.g., LPS) → Macrophages release IL-1, IL-6, TNF-α → Hypothalamic synthesis of PGE2 (via COX-2) → Increases set-point in Anterior Hypothalamus.
  • Physiologic Response: Shivering (to generate heat), Vasoconstriction (to conserve heat).
  • Treatment: NSAIDs/Acetaminophen (inhibit COX → decrease PGE2).
  • Hyperthermia vs. Fever: Fever respects the set-point (hypothalamus intact); Hyperthermia (e.g., Heat Stroke, Malignant Hyperthermia) overrides regulatory mechanisms.
content.takeAway: Fever is a hypothalamic response to cytokines (IL-1, IL-6) driven by PGE2, distinct from uncontrolled hyperthermia.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Infection/Inflammation] --> B[IL-1, IL-6, TNF-alpha]; B --> C[Hypothalamus]; C --> D[COX-2 Activation]; D --> E[PGE2 Synthesis]; E --> F[Increased Temperature Set Point];

content.definition: Gerstmann Syndrome is a cognitive disorder caused by a lesion in the dominant parietal lobe (specifically the Angular Gyrus), characterized by a tetrad of specific deficits.
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion: Dominant (usually Left) Inferior Parietal Lobule (Angular Gyrus).
  • Tetrad of Symptoms:
    1. Agraphia (Inability to write).
    2. Acalculia (Inability to calculate).
    3. Finger Agnosia (Inability to distinguish fingers).
    4. Left-Right Disorientation.
  • Etiology: [[middle_cerebral_artery]] stroke, tumor.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a patient who can't do math, write, or tell their left hand from their right.
content.takeAway: Gerstmann Syndrome localizes to the dominant angular gyrus, presenting with agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, and left-right confusion.

content.definition: Finger Agnosia is the inability to distinguish, name, or recognize one's own fingers or the fingers of others, typically associated with lesions of the dominant parietal lobe.
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Dominant Angular Gyrus (Parietal Lobe).
  • Significance: One of the four components of [[gerstmann_syndrome]].
  • Testing: Ask patient to "Show me your index finger" or identify which finger the examiner is touching.
content.takeAway: Finger Agnosia is a specific body schema disorder pointing to dominant parietal lobe dysfunction, often seen in Gerstmann Syndrome.

content.definition: Flaccid Paralysis is a form of paralysis characterized by loss of muscle tone (hypotonia) and absent deep tendon reflexes (areflexia), indicative of a [[lower_motor_neuron_lesion]] or acute spinal shock.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Interruption of the final common pathway (Anterior Horn Cell → Nerve → NMJ → Muscle).
  • Signs: Atrophy, Fasciculations, Hypotonia, Hyporeflexia.
  • Etiologies: [[polio]], [[guillain_barre_syndrome]], [[botulinum_toxin]], Spinal Muscular Atrophy, Cauda Equina Syndrome.
  • Contrast: Spastic Paralysis (UMN lesion).
content.takeAway: Flaccid Paralysis localizes pathology to the Lower Motor Neuron unit, presenting with limp muscles and absent reflexes.

content.definition: A Focal Aware Seizure (formerly Simple Partial) is a seizure arising from a specific area of one cerebral hemisphere where consciousness is preserved.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Features: Depends on location (e.g., Motor twitching, Sensory paresthesias, Autonomic changes, Psychic symptoms like déjà vu).
  • Key Feature: Patient remains awake and aware of the event.
  • Terminology: "Aura" is often a focal aware seizure.
  • Progression: Can evolve into Focal Impaired Awareness or Generalized Tonic-Clonic seizure.
content.takeAway: Focal Aware Seizures localize to a specific brain region and do not impair consciousness, often serving as a warning (aura) for larger seizures.

content.definition: A Focal Impaired Awareness Seizure (formerly Complex Partial) is a seizure arising from one hemisphere that results in an alteration of consciousness or awareness, often associated with automatisms.
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Most commonly Temporal Lobe (Mesial Temporal Sclerosis).
  • Clinical Features: Staring, unresponsiveness, Automatisms (lip smacking, picking at clothes, fumbling).
  • Post-ictal State: Confusion and lethargy (differentiates from Absence seizures).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from Absence: Focal has post-ictal confusion and lasts longer (>30s). Absence has immediate recovery.
content.takeAway: Focal Impaired Awareness Seizures involve altered consciousness and automatisms, classically originating in the temporal lobe, and are followed by a post-ictal state.

content.definition: Focal Seizures (Partial Seizures) originate within networks limited to one hemisphere of the brain, classified by awareness (Aware vs. Impaired Awareness) and motor onset.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - Focal Aware: No loss of consciousness.
    - Focal Impaired Awareness: Loss of consciousness/contact.
    - Focal to Bilateral Tonic-Clonic: Secondary generalization.
  • Etiologies: Structural lesions (Tumor, Stroke, scar tissue/gliosis), Infection, Vascular malformation.
  • Treatment: Narrow spectrum anticonvulsants (e.g., [[carbamazepine]], [[phenytoin]], [[gabapentin]]) or Broad spectrum (e.g., [[levetiracetam]], [[lamotrigine]]).
content.takeAway: Focal Seizures start locally and are often driven by structural pathology; treatment targets sodium channels or SV2A, unlike the T-type calcium channels targeted in absence epilepsy.

content.definition: The Foramen of Magendie is the single median aperture of the fourth ventricle that allows cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to exit the ventricular system into the cisterna magna of the subarachnoid space.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Midline of the roof of the 4th Ventricle.
  • Function: Outflow of CSF to Subarachnoid Space.
  • Relationship: Complemented by the two lateral Foramina of Luschka.
  • Mnemonic: Magendie is Medial. Luschka is Lateral.
  • Pathology: Obstruction leads to [[noncommunicating_hydrocephalus]].
content.takeAway: The Foramen of Magendie acts as the central drain for the fourth ventricle; its patency is essential for CSF circulation into the spinal and cranial subarachnoid spaces.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[4th Ventricle] -->|Foramen of Magendie| B[Cisterna Magna]; A -->|Foramina of Luschka| C[Pontine Cistern]; B & C --> D[Subarachnoid Space];

content.definition: The Foramen of Monro is the paired communication channel connecting the lateral ventricles to the third ventricle of the brain, allowing for the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Drains CSF from the Lateral Ventricles into the Third Ventricle.
  • Pathology:
    - Obstruction: Leads to dilation of the lateral ventricles (unilateral or bilateral) while the 3rd and 4th ventricles remain normal size. Common cause: Colloid Cyst of the third ventricle.
    - Result: [[noncommunicating_hydrocephalus]].
  • USMLE Tip: A "ball-valve" obstruction (e.g., Colloid Cyst) here can cause intermittent positional headaches and sudden death.
content.takeAway: The Foramen of Monro is the bottleneck between the lateral and third ventricles; blockage here causes specific enlargement of the lateral ventricles.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lateral Ventricles] -->|Foramen of Monro| B[Third Ventricle]; B -->|Cerebral Aqueduct| C[Fourth Ventricle];

content.definition: The Foramina of Luschka are the two lateral apertures of the fourth ventricle that allow cerebrospinal fluid to exit the ventricular system and enter the subarachnoid space (specifically the cerebellopontine angle cistern).
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Lateral recesses of the 4th Ventricle.
  • Function: Outflow of CSF to Subarachnoid Space.
  • Mnemonic: Luschka = Lateral (There are 2). Magendie = Medial (There is 1).
  • Pathology: Obstruction contributes to [[noncommunicating_hydrocephalus]] (along with Magendie obstruction).
content.takeAway: The Foramina of Luschka are the paired lateral drains of the fourth ventricle, complementing the medial Foramen of Magendie.

content.definition: Frataxin is a mitochondrial protein involved in iron-sulfur cluster assembly and iron homeostasis; decreased expression due to a trinucleotide repeat expansion causes [[friedreich_ataxia]].
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Regulates mitochondrial iron transport and respiration.
  • Pathology: Deficiency leads to mitochondrial iron accumulation → Oxidative stress (free radical damage) → Degeneration of nerve tissue (spinal cord/cerebellum) and heart.
  • Genetics: FXN gene on Chromosome 9. GAA repeat expansion in an intron (transcriptional silencing via heterochromatin).
  • USMLE Tip: Frataxin implies Fragile mitochondria due to Iron overload (Friedreich Ataxia).
content.takeAway: Frataxin deficiency leads to mitochondrial iron overload and oxidative damage, the central mechanism of [[friedreich_ataxia]].
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[GAA Repeat Expansion] --> B[Silencing of FXN Gene]; B --> C[Decreased Frataxin]; C --> D[Mitochondrial Iron Accumulation]; D --> E[Oxidative Stress / Free Radicals]; E --> F[Neuronal and Cardiac Death];

content.definition: Free Nerve Endings are unencapsulated sensory receptors found in the skin and viscera that function as nociceptors and thermoreceptors, detecting pain and temperature.
content.atAGlance:
• Fiber Types:
    - Aδ fibers: Fast, myelinated. Sharp/localized pain (and cold).
    - C fibers: Slow, unmyelinated. Dull/aching/burning pain (and warmth).
  • Location: Epidermis, dermis, cornea (purely free nerve endings), pulp of teeth, viscera.
  • Pathway: Synapse in dorsal horn → [[spinothalamic_tract]].
  • USMLE Tip: C fibers are blocked later than A fibers by pressure/hypoxia but blocked earlier by local anesthetics.
content.takeAway: Free Nerve Endings transduce pain and temperature via A-delta (fast) and C (slow) fibers, feeding into the [[spinothalamic_tract]].

content.definition: Fresh Frozen Plasma (FFP) is a blood product containing all clotting factors and plasma proteins, used to reverse coagulopathy (e.g., [[warfarin]] overdose, DIC, liver failure).
content.atAGlance:
• Contents: All coagulation factors (II, VII, IX, X, V, VIII, Fibrinogen, etc.), Antithrombin, Albumin.
  • Indications: Immediate reversal of Warfarin (if PCC not available), massive transfusion protocols, DIC, liver cirrhosis coagulopathy.
  • Comparison: Prothrombin Complex Concentrate (PCC) is preferred for Warfarin reversal (contains Factors II, VII, IX, X; lower volume, faster onset). FFP requires large volume (risk of TACO/TRALI).
  • USMLE Tip: For immediate Warfarin reversal: PCC > FFP. Vitamin K takes too long (hours/days).
content.takeAway: FFP replenishes all clotting factors and is used for acute reversal of coagulopathy, though PCC is preferred for Warfarin reversal due to volume considerations.

content.definition: Friedreich Ataxia is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion (GAA) in the FXN gene, leading to [[frataxin]] deficiency, mitochondrial dysfunction, and degeneration of multiple spinal tracts.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: AR, Chromosome 9. GAA repeat expansion ("Gaith Ataxic Always"). Frataxin deficiency → Iron overload in mitochondria.
  • Tracts Affected:
    1. Spinocerebellar: Ataxia, gait instability.
    2. Dorsal Columns: Loss of vibration/proprioception.
    3. Corticospinal: Weakness, UMN signs (Babinski).
    - Also: Dorsal root ganglia (loss of DTRs).
  • Clinical Features: Staggering gait (childhood), nystagmus, dysarthria, Pes Cavus (high arches), Hammer toes, Kyphoscoliosis.
  • Complications: Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (most common cause of death), Diabetes Mellitus.
  • USMLE Tip: Ataxia + Hammer Toes + Heart problems in a child = Friedreich Ataxia.
content.takeAway: Friedreich Ataxia involves the degeneration of the dorsal columns, corticospinal, and spinocerebellar tracts due to mitochondrial iron toxicity (GAA repeat/Frataxin), presenting with ataxia, skeletal deformities, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[GAA Expansion] --> B[Low Frataxin]; B --> C[Mitochondrial Iron Accumulation]; C --> D[ROS Damage]; D --> E[Degeneration of Neural Tracts]; D --> F[Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy]; E --> G[Ataxia / Weakness / Sensory Loss];

content.definition: The Frontal Eye Fields (FEF) are cortical areas located in the posterior middle frontal gyrus (Brodmann area 8) responsible for initiating voluntary rapid eye movements (saccades) to the contralateral side.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Generates horizontal saccades to the opposite side. (Left FEF pushes eyes Right).
  • Pathway: FEF → Contralateral [[paramedian_pontine_reticular_formation]] (PPRF) → CN VI Nucleus.
  • Lesions (Destructive): Eyes deviate toward the lesion. (Example: Left MCA stroke → Left FEF damage → Right gaze palsy → Eyes look Left).
  • Seizures (Irritative): Eyes deviate away from the lesion (seizure focus). (Example: Left FEF seizure → Eyes look Right).
  • USMLE Tip: "Right-Way Eyes" in stroke (looks at the lesion). "Wrong-Way Eyes" in seizure.
