content.takeAway: The Frontal Eye Fields control voluntary contralateral gaze; destructive lesions cause gaze deviation toward the lesion, while irritation causes deviation away.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Frontal Eye Field] -->|Stimulates| B[Contralateral PPRF]; B -->|Stimulates| C[CN VI Nucleus]; C --> D[Ipsilateral Lateral Rectus]; C -->|MLF| E[Contralateral CN III]; E --> F[Contralateral Medial Rectus];

content.definition: The Frontal Lobe is the largest lobe of the brain, located anterior to the central sulcus, responsible for motor function, executive function, personality, and language production ([[broca_area]]).
content.atAGlance:
• Key Areas:
    - Primary Motor Cortex: Voluntary movement (Precentral gyrus).
    - Premotor/Supplementary Motor: Planning movement.
    - [[frontal_eye_fields]]: Voluntary gaze.
    - [[broca_area]]: Speech production (Dominant hemisphere).
    - Prefrontal Cortex: Personality, judgment, social inhibition, concentration.
  • Pathology: [[frontal_lobe_syndrome]] (Disinhibition/Apathy), [[broca_aphasia]], Gaze deviation.
  • USMLE Tip: A change in personality or social behavior (e.g., Phineas Gage) localizes to the Prefrontal Cortex.
content.takeAway: The Frontal Lobe integrates motor output with executive control and personality; damage leads to weakness, aphasia, or profound behavioral changes.

content.definition: Frontal Lobe Syndrome refers to a constellation of behavioral and cognitive deficits resulting from damage to the prefrontal cortex, characterized by disinhibition, apathy, and impaired executive function.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - Disinhibited (Orbitofrontal): Impulsivity, social inappropriateness, poor judgment, emotional lability (e.g., Phineas Gage).
    - Apathetic (Dorsolateral): Lack of motivation (abulia), lethargy, poor planning/working memory.
  • Primitive Reflexes: Re-emergence of Suck, Grasp, Rooting, Glabellar reflexes ("Frontal Release Signs").
  • Etiologies: Trauma, [[frontotemporal_dementia]], Tumor (e.g., Butterfly glioma), Stroke (ACA).
  • USMLE Tip: "Witzelsucht" (inappropriate joking) is a sign of orbitofrontal damage.
content.takeAway: Frontal Lobe Syndrome manifests as a radical change in personality and behavior, ranging from chaotic disinhibition to profound apathy, often accompanied by primitive reflexes.

content.definition: Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by early, prominent changes in personality, behavior, and language (aphasia) due to selective atrophy of the frontal and temporal lobes, often sparing memory initially.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Variants:
    - Behavioral: Disinhibition, apathy, hyperorality, compulsive behaviors.
    - Primary Progressive Aphasia: Gradual loss of language function.
  • Pathology: Frontal/Temporal atrophy ("Knife-edge" gyri).
  • Histology:
    - Pick Bodies: Round, silver-staining inclusions of hyperphosphorylated Tau.
    - TDP-43: Ubiquitinated inclusions (associated with ALS).
  • Onset: Younger than Alzheimer's (40s-60s).
  • USMLE Tip: Dementia with personality changes coming before memory loss = FTD.
content.takeAway: Frontotemporal Dementia presents with early behavioral or language deficits due to lobar atrophy, histologically marked by Tau (Pick bodies) or TDP-43 inclusions.

content.definition: Funduscopic Examination is the visualization of the retina, optic disc, macula, and retinal vessels using an ophthalmoscope, crucial for diagnosing systemic and ocular pathology.
content.atAGlance:
• Key Findings:
    - [[papilledema]]: Blurring of optic disc margins (Increased ICP).
    - Cupping: Increased cup-to-disc ratio (Glaucoma).
    - [[cherry_red_spot]]: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion, Tay-Sachs.
    - AV Nicking/Cotton Wool Spots: Hypertension/Diabetes.
    - Drusen: Macular Degeneration.
    - Roth Spots: Endocarditis (white-centered hemorrhages).
  • USMLE Tip: It acts as a window to the brain (ICP) and microvasculature (HTN/Diabetes).
content.takeAway: Fundoscopy provides direct visualization of neurovascular health, identifying critical signs like papilledema (intracranial pressure) and vascular retinopathy.

content.definition: GABA (Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid) is the primary inhibitory neurotransmitter of the central nervous system, synthesized from glutamate by glutamate decarboxylase (GAD) using Vitamin B6 as a cofactor.
content.atAGlance:
• Synthesis: Glutamate → GABA (via GAD + Vitamin B6).
  • Metabolism: Broken down by GABA transaminase (requires B6).
  • Receptors:
    - GABAA: Ionotropic (Cl- channel) → Hyperpolarization. Target of [[benzodiazepines]], [[barbiturates]], Alcohol.
    - GABAB: Metabotropic (Gi) → K+ efflux. Target of [[baclofen]].
  • Pathology:
    - Decreased: [[anxiety_disorders]], [[huntington_disease]] (Loss of striatal GABA neurons).
    - Vitamin B6 Deficiency: Decreased GABA synthesis → Seizures.
  • Production Site: Nucleus Accumbens (Subcortex).
content.takeAway: GABA acts as the brain's main "brake," inducing inhibition via chloride influx or potassium efflux; its deficiency leads to anxiety and seizures, while its potentiation causes sedation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Glutamate] -->|GAD + B6| B[GABA]; B --> C[GABA-A Receptor]; B --> D[GABA-B Receptor]; C --> E[Cl- Influx]; D --> F[K+ Efflux]; E & F --> G[Hyperpolarization / Inhibition];

content.definition: The GABAA Receptor is a ligand-gated ion channel (ionotropic) that, upon binding GABA, opens a central pore allowing chloride (Cl-) influx, resulting in neuronal hyperpolarization and inhibition.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Ligand-gated Cl- channel. Activation → Cl- influx → Hyperpolarization → Decreased neuronal firing.
  • Pharmacology:
    - [[benzodiazepines]]: Increase Frequency of opening.
    - [[barbiturates]]: Increase Duration of opening.
    - Alcohol/Zolpidem: Bind specific sites to enhance activity.
  • Clinical Relevance: Target for sedatives, anxiolytics, and anticonvulsants. Withdrawal precipitates seizures due to receptor downregulation.
  • USMLE Tip: "Frenzodiazepines" (Frequency) vs "Barbidurates" (Duration).
content.takeAway: The GABAA Receptor mediates fast synaptic inhibition via chloride influx and is the site of action for major sedative-hypnotic drug classes.

content.definition: The GNAQ Gene encodes a G-protein alpha subunit; a somatic mosaic activating mutation in this gene is the underlying cause of [[sturge_weber_syndrome]] (Encephalotrigeminal Angiomatosis).
content.atAGlance:
• Mutation Type: Somatic mosaicism (post-zygotic mutation). Not inherited (sporadic).
  • Pathophysiology: Constitutive activation of G-protein signaling affects neural crest derivatives (vasculature).
  • Clinical Phenotype:
    - Port-Wine Stain: V1/V2 capillary malformation.
    - Leptomeningeal Angioma: Ipsilateral brain vascular malformation → Seizures, Calcification.
    - Glaucoma: Episcleral hemangioma.
  • USMLE Tip: Sturge-Weber is a GNAQ mutation. Think "Gnarly Neuro-Angioma Queue" (or just GNAQ = Sturge-Weber).
content.takeAway: A somatic mosaic mutation in the GNAQ gene drives the vascular malformations characteristic of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

content.definition: Gabapentin is an anticonvulsant and analgesic structurally related to GABA (but does not bind GABA receptors) that inhibits voltage-gated calcium channels (alpha-2-delta subunit), reducing excitatory neurotransmitter release.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Blocks voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (specifically the α2δ subunit) → decreased glutamate release.
  • Clinical Uses:
    - Neuropathic Pain: [[postherpetic_neuralgia]], Diabetic neuropathy.
    - Epilepsy: Focal seizures (adjunct).
  • Adverse Effects: Sedation, ataxia, dizziness, peripheral edema.
  • USMLE Tip: Despite the name, it does not work on GABA receptors. Primarily used for Neuropathic Pain.
content.takeAway: Gabapentin blocks calcium channels to treat neuropathic pain and focal seizures, causing sedation and ataxia as primary side effects.

content.definition: Gabapentinoids are a class of drugs including [[gabapentin]] and [[pregabalin]] that function by blocking the alpha-2-delta subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, thereby inhibiting the release of excitatory neurotransmitters.
content.atAGlance:
• Agents: Gabapentin, Pregabalin.
  • Mechanism: Inhibit presynaptic voltage-gated Ca2+ channels → decrease glutamate/substance P release.
  • Clinical Uses: Neuropathic pain (Diabetic, Postherpetic), Fibromyalgia, Focal seizures, Restless Legs Syndrome.
  • Adverse Effects: Dizziness, Sedation, Ataxia, Weight gain, Edema.
  • USMLE Tip: First-line agents for neuropathic pain.
content.takeAway: Gabapentinoids target calcium channels to dampen neuronal excitability, making them effective for neuropathic pain and seizures.

content.definition: The Gag Reflex (Pharyngeal Reflex) is a protective reflex contraction of the back of the throat elicited by touching the soft palate/pharynx, mediated by the afferent Glossopharyngeal (CN IX) and efferent Vagus (CN X) nerves.
content.atAGlance:
• Afferent Limb: [[glossopharyngeal_nerve]] (CN IX) (senses touch on posterior tongue/pharynx).
  • Efferent Limb: [[vagus_nerve]] (CN X) (elevates palate/pharynx).
  • Center: Medulla Oblongata.
  • Clinical Significance:
    - Absent: Lesion of CN IX, CN X, or Medulla (e.g., [[lateral_medullary_syndrome]], [[bulbar_palsy]]).
    - Hyperactive: UMN lesion (e.g., [[pseudobulbar_palsy]]).
  • USMLE Tip: "In on 9, Out on 10". Absent gag reflex puts patients at high risk for aspiration.
content.takeAway: The Gag Reflex tests the integrity of the IX-X reflex arc and the medulla; its absence indicates bulbar dysfunction, while hyperactivity suggests pseudobulbar palsy.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Touch Pharynx] --> B[CN IX Afferent]; B --> C[Medulla]; C --> D[CN X Efferent]; D --> E[Pharyngeal Constriction/Elevation];

content.definition: The Galant Reflex (Truncal Incurvation Reflex) is a primitive reflex present in newborns where stroking along one side of the spine creates lateral flexion of the lower body toward the stimulated side.
content.atAGlance:
• Elicitation: Hold infant in ventral suspension (face down); stroke paravertebral skin.
  • Response: Spine curves toward stimulus (buttocks swing toward touch).
  • Timeline: Present at birth, disappears by ~6-9 months.
  • Clinical Significance: Absence suggests spinal cord lesion; persistence suggests delayed development or cerebral palsy (frontal lobe inhibition failure).
  • USMLE Tip: Primitive reflexes disappear as the frontal lobe matures.
content.takeAway: The Galant Reflex helps assess spinal cord integrity in newborns and should disappear in the first year of life.

content.definition: Galantamine is a centrally acting, reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used to treat the cognitive symptoms of mild to moderate [[alzheimer_disease]] by increasing synaptic acetylcholine.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Competitive inhibition of AChE → Increases ACh levels in the CNS. Also acts as an allosteric modulator of nicotinic receptors.
  • Clinical Use: [[alzheimer_disease]].
  • Adverse Effects: Cholinergic toxicity (Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, bradycardia).
  • USMLE Tip: Part of the "Donepezil, Rivastigmine, Galantamine" trio for Alzheimer's symptomatic management.
content.takeAway: Galantamine boosts cholinergic transmission to treat Alzheimer's dementia, targeting the ACh deficit caused by basal forebrain degeneration.

content.definition: Vertical Gaze Palsy is the inability to move the eyes vertically (usually upgaze), typically caused by a lesion in the dorsal midbrain involving the vertical gaze center (rostral interstitial nucleus of MLF/superior colliculus).
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Dorsal Midbrain (Tectum/Pretectum).
  • Etiologies:
    - [[pineal_gland_tumor]] (Pinealoma): Compresses the superior colliculus.
    - Hydrocephalus: Dilation of cerebral aqueduct.
    - Stroke: Midbrain infarction.
  • Clinical Syndrome: Hallmark of [[parinaud_syndrome]] (Dorsal Midbrain Syndrome).
  • Associated Findings: Light-near dissociation, Convergence-retraction nystagmus, Eyelid retraction.
  • USMLE Tip: Patient cannot look up + Headache + Child = Pinealoma (Parinaud Syndrome).
content.takeAway: Vertical Gaze Palsy localizes to the dorsal midbrain and is the cardinal sign of Parinaud Syndrome, most often caused by a pineal tumor compressing the tectal plate.

content.definition: Generalized Seizures involve epileptiform activity occurring in both cerebral hemispheres simultaneously from onset, characterized by loss of consciousness (except myoclonic) and bilateral motor manifestations.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - [[absence_seizure]]: Staring, 3Hz spike-wave (Ethosuximide).
    - [[tonic_clonic_seizure]]: Stiffening + Jerking.
    - [[myoclonic_seizure]]: Quick jerks (no LOC).
    - [[atonic_seizure]]: Drop attacks.
    - Tonic: Stiffening only.
  • Treatment: [[broad_spectrum_anticonvulsants]] (Valproate, Levetiracetam, Lamotrigine, Topiramate).
  • USMLE Tip: Avoid narrow spectrum drugs (Carbamazepine, Phenytoin) for generalized seizures as they may worsen Absence/Myoclonic seizures.
content.takeAway: Generalized Seizures engage the entire brain at onset, necessitating broad-spectrum anticonvulsants like Valproate or Levetiracetam for management.

content.definition: Geriatric Neurology encompasses the age-related changes and pathologies affecting the nervous system in the elderly, characterized by brain atrophy, increased susceptibility to vascular insults, and neurodegenerative processes.
content.atAGlance:
• Physiologic Changes: Brain atrophy (widened sulci, ventriculomegaly ex vacuo), decreased neurotransmitters, lipofuscin accumulation.
  • Pathology Risk:
    - [[subdural_hematoma]]: Atrophy stretches bridging veins → rupture with minor trauma.
    - [[normal_pressure_hydrocephalus]]: Gait apraxia, incontinence, dementia.
    - Dementia: [[alzheimer_disease]], [[vascular_dementia]].
    - Stroke/TIA: Increased risk.
  • Pharmacology: Increased sensitivity to anticholinergics (delirium) and benzodiazepines (falls).
  • USMLE Tip: Bridging veins tear easily in the elderly due to brain atrophy (Subdural).
content.takeAway: Geriatric Neurology is defined by the consequences of brain atrophy (subdural risk) and neurodegeneration, requiring careful differentiation between normal aging and pathologic dementia.

content.definition: Gerstmann Syndrome is a cognitive disorder caused by a lesion in the dominant parietal lobe (Angular Gyrus), characterized by the tetrad of agraphia, acalculia, finger agnosia, and left-right disorientation.
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Dominant (Left) Inferior Parietal Lobule (Angular Gyrus).
  • Tetrad:
    1. [[agraphia]]: Can't write.
    2. [[acalculia]]: Can't calculate.
    3. [[finger_agnosia]]: Can't identify fingers.
    4. Left-Right Disorientation.
  • Etiology: [[middle_cerebral_artery]] stroke (parietal branch).
content.takeAway: Gerstmann Syndrome localizes to the dominant angular gyrus, presenting with the specific tetrad of acalculia, agraphia, finger agnosia, and left-right confusion.

content.definition: Ghrelin is an orexigenic (appetite-stimulating) peptide hormone secreted primarily by the stomach that acts on the [[hypothalamus]] to increase hunger and stimulate growth hormone release.
content.atAGlance:
• Source: Gastric cells (Stomach).
  • Action: Stimulates lateral [[hypothalamus]] → Increases appetite/hunger. Stimulates GH secretion.
  • Regulation: Increased in fasting/sleep deprivation; Decreased after meals.
  • Pathology:
    - [[prader_willi_syndrome]]: Elevated Ghrelin contributes to hyperphagia.
    - Gastric Bypass: Removes Ghrelin-secreting cells → reduced appetite.
  • USMLE Tip: "Ghrelin makes your stomach grrowl." It opposes [[leptin]].
content.takeAway: Ghrelin is the "hunger hormone" from the stomach, driving appetite via the lateral hypothalamus and notably elevated in Prader-Willi syndrome.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Fasting] --> B[Stomach Secretes Ghrelin]; B --> C[Lateral Hypothalamus]; C --> D[Increased Appetite]; B --> E[Anterior Pituitary]; E --> F[Increased Growth Hormone];

content.definition: Glatiramer Acetate is an immunomodulatory drug used to treat [[multiple_sclerosis]], consisting of a random polymer of four amino acids found in myelin basic protein, acting as a decoy to divert autoimmune attack.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Resembles Myelin Basic Protein. Acts as a Decoy for T-cells → shifts immune response from Th1 (pro-inflammatory) to Th2 (anti-inflammatory).
  • Clinical Use: Relapsing-Remitting [[multiple_sclerosis]] (Disease Modifying Therapy).
  • Adverse Effects: Injection site reactions, flushing, chest tightness.
  • USMLE Tip: The "Glat" stands for Glutamic acid, Lysine, Alanine, Tyrosine (the 4 amino acids). Mechanism = Decoy.
content.takeAway: Glatiramer acts as a myelin decoy to modulate the immune system in multiple sclerosis, reducing relapse rates.

content.definition: Glaucoma is a group of optic neuropathies characterized by progressive structural damage to the optic nerve (optic disc cupping) and visual field loss (peripheral to central), usually associated with elevated [[intraocular_pressure]] (IOP) due to impaired aqueous humor drainage.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - [[open_angle_glaucoma]]: Chronic, painless. Increased resistance to outflow through trabecular meshwork.
    - [[angle_closure_glaucoma]]: Acute, painful emergency. Physical obstruction of the angle by the iris.
  • Fundoscopy: Increased cup-to-disc ratio ("cupping") due to loss of nerve fibers.
  • Visual Field: Peripheral vision loss followed by central loss.
  • Treatment:
    - Decrease Production: [[beta_blockers]] (Timolol), Alpha-2 agonists ([[brimonidine]]), [[acetazolamide]].
    - Increase Outflow: [[prostaglandin_analogs]] (Latanoprost), Muscarinic agonists ([[pilocarpine]]).
  • USMLE Tip: Disc cupping > 0.5 is suggestive. Treat Open-angle with Prostaglandins (1st line); Treat Closed-angle with Iridotomy (definitive).
content.takeAway: Glaucoma is an optic neuropathy driven by intraocular pressure, leading to "cupping" of the optic disc and peripheral vision loss; management targets aqueous humor dynamics.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Increased IOP] --> B[Optic Nerve Compression]; B --> C[Retinal Ganglion Cell Death]; C --> D[Optic Disc Cupping]; D --> E[Peripheral Vision Loss];

content.definition: Glial Cells (Neuroglia) are the non-neuronal support cells of the nervous system, providing physical support, insulation (myelin), and metabolic maintenance for neurons.
content.atAGlance:
• CNS Glia (Neuroectoderm):
    - [[astrocytes]]: BBB support, K+ metabolism, repair (gliosis). GFAP+.
    - [[oligodendrocytes]]: Myelinate multiple CNS axons. "Fried egg" appearance.
    - [[ependymal_cells]]: Line ventricles, produce CSF.
    - [[microglia]] (Mesoderm): Phagocytes (CNS macrophages).
  • PNS Glia (Neural Crest):
    - [[schwann_cells]]: Myelinate single PNS axon. S-100+.
    - Satellite Cells: Support ganglia.
  • USMLE Tip: Microglia are the only glia derived from Mesoderm; all others are Neuroectoderm/Neural Crest.
content.takeAway: Glial Cells maintain the neural environment; Astrocytes support, Oligodendrocytes/Schwann cells myelinate, and Microglia defend.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Neural Stem Cell] --> B[Glioblast]; B --> C[Astrocyte]; B --> D[Oligodendrocyte]; E[Mesoderm] --> F[Microglia]; G[Neural Crest] --> H[Schwann Cell];

content.definition: Glioblastoma (GBM, WHO Grade IV Astrocytoma) is the most common and most malignant primary brain tumor in adults, characterized by rapid infiltrative growth and necrosis.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathology: "Pseudopalisading" tumor cells surrounding central necrosis. Vascular proliferation. GFAP positive.
  • Gross Anatomy: Hemorrhagic, necrotic mass often crossing the corpus callosum ("Butterfly Glioma").
  • Genetics: EGFR amplification, PTEN loss.
  • Clinical: Seizures, headache, focal deficits. Rapid progression (< 1 year survival).
  • USMLE Tip: "Pseudopalisading necrosis" and "Butterfly lesion" are the buzzwords.
content.takeAway: Glioblastoma is a high-grade astrocyte tumor with a dismal prognosis, identified by its butterfly appearance on imaging and pseudopalisading necrosis on histology.

content.definition: Global Aphasia is the most severe form of aphasia, characterized by the impairment of all language modalities (fluency, comprehension, and repetition), resulting from extensive damage to the dominant hemisphere.
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion: Extensive damage to the Left Perisylvian region, affecting both [[broca_area]] and [[wernicke_area]] (and the [[arcuate_fasciculus]]).
  • Etiology: Large [[middle_cerebral_artery]] (MCA) infarct (Main stem occlusion).
  • Clinical: Non-fluent/mute speech, poor comprehension, poor repetition. Often accompanied by dense right hemiparesis and hemianopsia.
  • USMLE Tip: The patient can neither speak nor understand. Look for a massive Left MCA stroke.
content.takeAway: Global Aphasia represents a "wipe-out" of the language centers, causing non-fluent speech and loss of comprehension, typically due to a proximal MCA occlusion.

content.definition: The Globose Nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei (part of the Interposed Nuclei) that regulates muscle tone and limb movement via projections to the Red Nucleus.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Medial to the Emboliform, lateral to the Fastigial nucleus.
  • Function: Works with the Emboliform nucleus to control proximal limb muscles.
  • Input: Paravermis (Spinocerebellum).
  • Output: Contralateral Red Nucleus (Rubrospinal tract).
  • Mnemonic: "Globose" is in the middle of "Don't Eat Greasy Foods".
content.takeAway: The Globose Nucleus is a deep cerebellar nucleus involved in adjusting limb movements, functioning as part of the Interposed Nuclei.

content.definition: The Globus Pallidus Externus (GPe) is a nucleus of the [[basal_ganglia]] that serves as a central relay in the Indirect Pathway, tonically inhibiting the Subthalamic Nucleus to regulate movement.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Inhibits the [[subthalamic_nucleus]] (STN) via GABA.
  • Indirect Pathway: Striatum (D2) inhibits GPe → GPe releases STN → STN excites GPi → GPi inhibits Thalamus → Decreased Movement.
  • Neurotransmitter: GABA (Inhibitory).
  • USMLE Tip: In the Indirect Pathway, the GPe acts as the "inhibitor of the inhibitor." Inhibition of GPe releases the STN brake.
content.takeAway: The Globus Pallidus Externus is the GABAergic relay of the Indirect Pathway; its inhibition by the striatum leads to suppression of movement via the subthalamic nucleus.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Striatum D2] --Inhibits--> B[Globus Pallidus Externus]; B --Inhibits--> C[Subthalamic Nucleus]; C --Excites--> D[Globus Pallidus Internus]; D --Inhibits--> E[Thalamus];

content.definition: The Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX) is a mixed cranial nerve serving sensory, motor, and autonomic functions for the posterior tongue, pharynx, and parotid gland.
content.atAGlance:
• Sensory: Taste and Somatic sensation to Posterior 1/3 of Tongue; Tonsils; Pharynx; Middle Ear.
  • Visceral Sensory: Carotid Body (Chemoreceptors) and Carotid Sinus (Baroreceptors).
  • Motor: Stylopharyngeus muscle (elevates pharynx/larynx).
  • Parasympathetic: Parotid Gland (via Otic Ganglion).
  • Reflex: Afferent limb of the [[gag_reflex]].
  • Lesions: Loss of gag reflex, loss of taste/sensation post. 1/3 tongue, dysphagia.
content.takeAway: CN IX is the nerve of the posterior tongue and pharynx, governing taste, sensation, swallowing (afferent gag), and parotid secretion.

content.definition: Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone (GnRH) is a decapeptide produced by the preoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus that stimulates the anterior pituitary to secrete FSH and LH in a pulsatile manner.
content.atAGlance:
• Source: Preoptic nucleus of the [[hypothalamus]].
  • Target: Gonadotrophs in the [[adenohypophysis]].
  • Action: Stimulates release of FSH and LH.
  • Regulation: Pulsatile release is required for stimulation. Continuous administration (e.g., [[leuprolide]]) leads to downregulation/suppression (chemical castration).
  • Pathology: Kallmann Syndrome (failure of GnRH neuron migration) → Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism + Anosmia.
  • USMLE Tip: Prolactin inhibits GnRH release (mechanism of lactational amenorrhea).
content.takeAway: GnRH drives the reproductive axis via pulsatile stimulation of the pituitary; its continuous analogs are used to suppress the axis in conditions like prostate cancer or endometriosis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypothalamus] -->|Pulsatile GnRH| B[Anterior Pituitary]; B --> C[FSH/LH Release]; C --> D[Gonads]; E[Continuous GnRH] --x|Downregulation| B;

content.definition: A Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizure (Grand Mal) is a type of seizure involving the entire brain, characterized by an initial tonic phase (stiffening, loss of consciousness) followed by a clonic phase (rhythmic jerking), and a postictal state.
content.atAGlance:
• Phases:
    1. Tonic: Sudden loss of consciousness, diffuse muscle contraction (stiffening), "ictal cry" (expiration against closed glottis).
    2. Clonic: Rhythmic jerking of limbs.
    3. Postictal: Confusion, lethargy, gradual return to baseline.
  • Physiology: Diffuse, synchronous electrical discharges across both hemispheres.
  • Management: ABCs. Abort with [[benzodiazepines]] if prolonged. Maintenance with [[valproate]], [[levetiracetam]], or [[lamotrigine]].
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from syncope (quick recovery, no postictal confusion). Lateral tongue biting implies seizure.
content.takeAway: Tonic-Clonic Seizures are the most dramatic generalized seizures, involving stiffening and jerking followed by profound postictal confusion; they require broad-spectrum anticonvulsants.

content.definition: Guillain-Barré Syndrome is an acute, autoimmune, demyelinating polyradiculopathy of the peripheral nervous system, characterized by ascending muscle weakness, areflexia, and albuminocytologic dissociation.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Autoimmune attack on Schwann cells/myelin (or axons) via molecular mimicry following infection (e.g., [[campylobacter_jejuni]], CMV, Zika).
  • Clinical Presentation: Symmetric Ascending Paralysis (Legs → Arms → Face/Respiratory). Absent DTRs. Autonomic dysregulation (arrhythmias, BP lability).
  • Diagnosis: CSF shows [[albuminocytologic_dissociation]] (High protein, normal cells). Nerve conduction studies show slowing.
  • Treatment: IVIG or Plasmapheresis. Supportive care (ventilator). Steroids are ineffective.
  • USMLE Tip: The most common cause of acute flaccid paralysis. Monitor Vital Capacity for respiratory failure.
content.takeAway: GBS is an acute post-infectious demyelinating neuropathy causing ascending paralysis; diagnosis relies on CSF findings (high protein), and management focuses on respiratory support and immunotherapy.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Campylobacter Infection] --> B[Antibody Production]; B --> C[Cross-reaction with Peripheral Nerve Gangliosides]; C --> D[Schwann Cell Damage]; D --> E[Demyelination]; E --> F[Ascending Weakness/Areflexia];

content.definition: The Gustatory Pathway carries taste sensation from the tongue via cranial nerves VII, IX, and X to the Nucleus Tractus Solitarius, then to the VPM of the thalamus, and finally to the gustatory cortex.
content.atAGlance:
• Afferent Nerves:
    - Ant 2/3 Tongue: [[facial_nerve]] (Chorda Tympani).
    - Post 1/3 Tongue: [[glossopharyngeal_nerve]].
    - Epiglottis/Pharynx: [[vagus_nerve]].
  • First Relay: [[nucleus_tractus_solitarius]] (Medulla).
  • Second Relay: [[ventral_posteromedial_nucleus]] (VPM) of the Thalamus.
  • Cortex: Gustatory Cortex (Insula/Frontal Operculum).
  • USMLE Tip: VPM = Mouth/Face (Taste + Trigeminal sensation).
content.takeAway: Taste travels via CN VII, IX, and X to the solitary nucleus, then relays through the thalamic VPM to reach the cortex.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Tongue Taste Buds] --> B[CN VII/IX/X]; B --> C[Nucleus Tractus Solitarius]; C --> D[VPM of Thalamus]; D --> E[Gustatory Cortex];

content.definition: HIV-Associated Dementia is a subcortical dementia occurring in advanced HIV infection, caused by direct viral neurotoxicity and macrophage activation, leading to microglial nodules and multinucleated giant cells.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: HIV infects microglia/macrophages (via CCR5/CXCR4) → Cytokine release/Neurotoxicity. Neurons are not directly infected.
  • Histology: Microglial Nodules with Multinucleated Giant Cells. Diffuse white matter pallor.
  • Clinical Presentation: Subcortical dementia: Psychomotor slowing, impaired attention, memory deficits, gait disturbance, depressive symptoms.
  • Imaging: Cerebral atrophy, diffuse white matter hyperintensities.
  • USMLE Tip: "Multinucleated giant cells" in the brain of an AIDS patient = HIV Encephalitis.
content.takeAway: HIV Dementia is a direct consequence of HIV infection of CNS microglia, forming characteristic nodules and giant cells, causing a subcortical cognitive decline.

content.definition: Haemophilus influenzae is a Gram-negative coccobacillus that requires Factors V (NAD+) and X (Hematin) for growth, causing respiratory infections and, in unvaccinated children (Type b), serious invasive diseases like [[meningitis]] and [[epiglottitis]].
content.atAGlance:
• Characteristics: Gram(-) coccobacillus. Growth on Chocolate Agar (provides Factors V and X).
  • Serotypes:
    - Type b (Capsular): Polyribosylribitol phosphate (PRP) capsule. Causes Meningitis, Epiglottitis, Septic Arthritis.
    - Non-typeable (Unencapsulated): Mucosal infections ([[otitis_media]], Sinusitis, Pneumonia, COPD exacerbations).
  • Virulence: IgA Protease, Capsule (Type b).
  • Prevention: Hib Vaccine (Capsule conjugated to diphtheria toxoid) → drastic reduction in meningitis/epiglottitis.
  • USMLE Tip: Can grow on Blood Agar only if surrounding S. aureus ("Satellite Phenomenon" - Staph provides Factor V).
content.takeAway: Haemophilus influenzae requires chocolate agar; Type b causes invasive meningitis/epiglottitis (prevented by vaccine), while non-typeable strains cause common mucosal infections like otitis media.

content.definition: Hamartin is the protein product of the TSC1 gene (Chromosome 9), which forms a complex with [[tuberin]] (TSC2) to inhibit the mTOR pathway, acting as a tumor suppressor; its mutation causes [[tuberous_sclerosis]].
content.atAGlance:
• Gene: TSC1 on Chromosome 9.
  • Function: Forms a complex with Tuberin (TSC2). This complex acts as a GTPase-activating protein (GAP) for Rheb, thereby inhibiting mTOR (mechanistic target of rapamycin).
  • Pathology: Loss of function → uncontrolled mTOR activation → cell growth/proliferation → Hamartomas.
  • Clinical Syndrome: [[tuberous_sclerosis]] (Hamartomas in brain/skin/heart/kidney, Seizures, Intellectual disability).
  • USMLE Tip: TSC1 = Hamartin. TSC2 = Tuberin.
content.takeAway: Hamartin (TSC1) works with Tuberin to suppress mTOR; defects lead to the multi-system hamartomas of Tuberous Sclerosis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[TSC1 (Hamartin)] --- B[TSC2 (Tuberin)]; A & B -->|Inhibit| C[mTOR Pathway]; D[Mutation in TSC1] --> E[Unchecked mTOR]; E --> F[Cell Growth/Hamartomas];

content.definition: Headache Disorders are classified into primary (no underlying structural cause) and secondary (symptom of underlying pathology) types, with distinct clinical features and management strategies.
content.atAGlance:
• Primary Headaches:
    - [[tension_headache]]: Bilateral, band-like, no photophobia/aura.
    - [[migraine]]: Unilateral, pulsating, photophobia/phonophobia, aura (scintillating scotoma). POUND mnemonic.
    - [[cluster_headache]]: Unilateral periorbital, excruciating, autonomic symptoms (lacrimation, rhinorrhea), circadian rhythm.
  • Secondary Headaches: [[subarachnoid_hemorrhage]] ("Thunderclap"), [[idiopathic_intracranial_hypertension]], [[giant_cell_arteritis]], Meningitis, Tumor.
  • USMLE Tip: "Worst headache of my life" = SAH. "Band-like" = Tension. "Periorbital + Tearing" = Cluster.
content.takeAway: Headache Disorders are distinguished by duration, location, and associated symptoms; Migraines are vascular/neuronal, Tension is musculoskeletal/stress, and Cluster is autonomic/hypothalamic.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Headache] --> B{Primary or Secondary?}; B -->|Primary| C{Features?}; C -->|Bilateral/Band-like| D[Tension]; C -->|Unilateral/Pulsating| E[Migraine]; C -->|Periorbital/Autonomic| F[Cluster]; B -->|Secondary| G[Red Flags]; G -->|Thunderclap| H[Subarachnoid Hemorrhage]; G -->|Fever/Nuchal Rigidity| I[Meningitis];

content.definition: Hearing Loss is the partial or total inability to hear, classified anatomically into Conductive (outer/middle ear) and Sensorineural (inner ear/cochlear nerve) types, distinguished by the Rinne and Weber tuning fork tests.
content.atAGlance:
• [[conductive_hearing_loss]]: Obstruction (wax), Otitis media, Otosclerosis, Cholesteatoma. Rinne: Bone > Air. Weber: Localizes to affected ear.
  • [[sensorineural_hearing_loss]]: [[presbycusis]] (aging), [[noise_induced_hearing_loss]], Drugs (Aminoglycosides, Cisplatin), Meniere's, Acoustic Neuroma. Rinne: Air > Bone (Normal). Weber: Localizes to unaffected ear.
  • Presbycusis: Bilateral high-frequency loss due to hair cell destruction at the cochlear base.
  • USMLE Tip: Weber goes to the Weaker ear in Conductive, Stronger ear in Sensorineural.
content.takeAway: Hearing Loss is categorized by the site of pathology; Conductive involves sound transmission failure (Bone > Air), while Sensorineural involves nerve/cochlear failure (Air > Bone, lateralizes to good ear).
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hearing Loss] --> B{Weber Test}; B -->|Lateralizes to Bad Ear| C[Conductive Loss]; B -->|Lateralizes to Good Ear| D[Sensorineural Loss]; C --> E[Rinne: BC > AC]; D --> F[Rinne: AC > BC];

content.definition: Heat Stroke is a life-threatening condition defined by a core body temperature >40°C (104°F) accompanied by CNS dysfunction (confusion, coma, seizures) due to failure of thermoregulation.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Failure of evaporative cooling (sweating) → Rapid rise in core temp → Denaturation of proteins/enzymes → Multiorgan failure.
  • Clinical Presentation: Hyperthermia (>40°C), Altered Mental Status, Anhidrosis (hot, dry skin - classic) or Profuse sweating (exertional).
  • Complications: Rhabdomyolysis, Acute Kidney Injury, DIC, ARDS.
  • Treatment: Rapid external cooling (ice water immersion), rehydration.
  • Differentiation: Contrast with Fever (cytokine-mediated set-point change, managed with antipyretics). Heat stroke is not cytokine-mediated; antipyretics do not work.
content.takeAway: Heat Stroke is a medical emergency of thermoregulatory failure causing hyperthermia and CNS dysfunction, requiring rapid physical cooling rather than antipyretics.

content.definition: Hemangioblastoma is a slow-growing, highly vascular benign tumor of the central nervous system, most commonly found in the cerebellum, often associated with [[von_hippel_lindau_disease]].
content.atAGlance:
• Histology: Closely packed, thin-walled capillaries with intervening stromal cells containing lipid vacuoles.
  • Location: Cerebellum (most common), Brainstem, Spinal Cord, Retina.
  • Paraneoplastic Syndrome: Can produce Erythropoietin (EPO) → [[polycythemia]] (Secondary).
  • Genetics: Associated with VHL gene deletion on Chromosome 3p (Von Hippel-Lindau).
  • Imaging: Cystic lesion with a vascular mural nodule.
  • USMLE Tip: Cerebellar tumor + Polycythemia = Hemangioblastoma.
content.takeAway: Hemangioblastomas are vascular cerebellar tumors that may secrete EPO causing polycythemia and are a hallmark of Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

content.definition: Hemianopia is a visual field defect characterized by the loss of vision in half of the visual field of one or both eyes, localizing lesions to the optic chiasm, optic tract, or visual cortex.
content.atAGlance:
• [[bitemporal_hemianopia]]: Loss of both temporal fields ("Tunnel vision"). Lesion: Optic Chiasm (e.g., Pituitary Adenoma).
  • Homonymous Hemianopia: Loss of the same side in both eyes (e.g., Left visual field of both eyes). Lesion: Retro-chiasmal (Optic Tract, LGN, Optic Radiations, Visual Cortex).
  • Macular Sparing: Seen in Occipital Lobe lesions (PCA infarct) because the macula has dual blood supply (MCA + PCA).
  • USMLE Tip: Right PCA stroke → Left Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing.
content.takeAway: Hemianopia patterns localize lesions along the visual pathway: Chiasmal lesions cause bitemporal defects, while retro-chiasmal lesions cause contralateral homonymous defects.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Optic Chiasm Lesion] --> B[Bitemporal Hemianopia]; C[Optic Tract/Radiation Lesion] --> D[Contralateral Homonymous Hemianopia]; E[PCA Stroke] --> F[Homonymous Hemianopia w/ Macular Sparing];

content.definition: Hemiballismus is a hyperkinetic movement disorder characterized by involuntary, violent, large-amplitude flinging movements of the contralateral limbs, caused by a lesion in the [[subthalamic_nucleus]].
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Contralateral Subthalamic Nucleus (STN).
  • Mechanism: STN lesion → Loss of excitation to GPi → Reduced inhibition of Thalamus → Excessive movement. (Indirect pathway failure).
  • Etiology: Classic cause is a Lacunar Stroke (posterior limb of internal capsule or STN). Can also be hyperglycemic non-ketotic state.
  • USMLE Tip: "Flinging" or "Ballistic" movements of one side = Contralateral Subthalamic Nucleus lesion.
content.takeAway: Hemiballismus involves violent contralateral limb flinging due to disinhibition of the thalamus following damage to the subthalamic nucleus.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[STN Lesion] --> B[Decreased Excitation of GPi]; B --> C[Decreased Inhibition of Thalamus]; C --> D[Increased Thalamocortical Drive]; D --> E[Hemiballismus];

content.definition: Hemispatial Neglect is a deficit in attention to and awareness of one side of space (usually the left), occurring despite intact sensory and motor function, caused by a lesion in the non-dominant parietal lobe (usually Right).
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion: Right (Non-dominant) Posterior Parietal Lobe (Brodmann 5, 7).
  • Clinical Presentation: Patient ignores the Left side of the world. Shaves only right face, draws clock with numbers only on right, eats from right side of plate.
  • Mechanism: The Right hemisphere attends to both sides of space; the Left hemisphere attends only to the Right. Right lesion = Loss of Left attention. Left lesion = Right hemisphere compensates (so minimal/no neglect).
  • USMLE Tip: "Clock drawing test" is abnormal (numbers crowded on right).
content.takeAway: Hemispatial Neglect is a profound attention deficit to the left hemispace caused by damage to the right parietal cortex.

content.definition: Brain Herniation is the displacement of brain tissue across rigid dural folds (falx, tentorium) or through skull openings due to elevated [[intracranial_pressure]], leading to compression of vital structures.
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    1. [[cingulate_herniation]] (Subfalcine): Cingulate gyrus under falx cerebri. Compresses ACA (Contralateral leg weakness).
    2. [[uncal_herniation]] (Transtentorial): Uncus (temporal lobe) over tentorium. Compresses CN III (Blown pupil), PCA (Blindness), Cerebral Peduncle (Hemiparesis).
    3. [[cerebellar_tonsillar_herniation]]: Tonsils through foramen magnum. Compresses Medulla (Respiratory arrest).
    4. Central (Downward): Diencephalon downward. Duret hemorrhages.
  • USMLE Tip: Blown pupil = Uncal. Resp arrest = Tonsillar. Leg weakness = Subfalcine.
content.takeAway: Brain Herniation is the lethal consequence of untreated ICP; specific syndromes (Uncal, Tonsillar, Subfalcine) are defined by the structure displaced and the adjacent anatomy compressed.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Increased ICP] --> B{Location?}; B -->|Supratentorial Lateral| C[Uncal Herniation]; B -->|Supratentorial Midline| D[Central Herniation]; B -->|Posterior Fossa| E[Tonsillar Herniation]; C --> F[CN III / Midbrain Compression]; E --> G[Medullary Compression];

content.definition: Intracranial Hemorrhage refers to bleeding within the skull, classified by location relative to the meninges and brain parenchyma, including epidural, subdural, subarachnoid, and intraparenchymal types.
content.atAGlance:
• [[epidural_hematoma]]: Arterial (MMA), Lens-shaped (Biconvex), Lucid interval.
  • [[subdural_hematoma]]: Venous (Bridging veins), Crescent-shaped, Elderly/Alcoholics.
  • [[subarachnoid_hemorrhage]]: Arterial (Aneurysm), "Worst headache," Bloody CSF.
  • [[intraparenchymal_hemorrhage]]: Systemic HTN (Basal Ganglia), Amyloid Angiopathy (Lobar).
  • Neonatal: [[intraventricular_hemorrhage]] (Germinal matrix fragility in preemies).
content.takeAway: Intracranial Hemorrhages are distinguished by vessel origin (arterial vs. venous) and CT appearance (Lens vs. Crescent vs. Diffuse), guiding urgent management.

content.definition: Drug-Induced Liver Injury (Hepatotoxicity) implies hepatic damage caused by medications, ranging from mild enzyme elevation to fulminant liver failure, mediated by direct toxicity or idiosyncratic reactions.
content.atAGlance:
• Key Culprits:
    - [[acetaminophen]]: Direct toxicity (NAPQI).
    - [[isoniazid]] (INH): Hepatocellular necrosis.
    - [[valproate]]: Microvesicular fatty change.
    - [[halothane]]: Immune-mediated massive necrosis.
    - Statins, Methotrexate, Amiodarone.
  • Patterns:
    - Hepatocellular: ALT/AST elevation (INH, Acetaminophen).
    - Cholestatic: ALP/Bilirubin elevation (Erythromycin, Oral Contraceptives).
  • USMLE Tip: Always check LFTs before starting Statins, INH, or Valproate.
content.takeAway: Hepatotoxicity is a major adverse effect of drugs like Acetaminophen, Isoniazid, and Valproate, necessitating monitoring of liver function.

content.definition: Spinal Cord Hemisection is the pathological transection or damage of one lateral half of the spinal cord, resulting in the clinical syndrome known as [[brown_sequard_syndrome]].
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: Unilateral damage to ascending and descending tracts.
  • Tracts Affected:
    - Dorsal Column: Ipsilateral loss of proprioception/vibration.
    - Corticospinal Tract: Ipsilateral motor weakness (UMN).
    - Spinothalamic Tract: Contralateral loss of pain/temperature (1-2 levels below).
  • Etiology: Penetrating trauma (knife, bullet), lateral tumor compression, demyelination (MS).
content.takeAway: Spinal Cord Hemisection is the structural lesion that produces the dissociated sensory and motor deficits of Brown-Séquard Syndrome.

content.definition: (Placeholder) A group of inherited disorders affecting peripheral nerves, most commonly referring to [[charcot_marie_tooth_disease]].
content.atAGlance: • See [[charcot_marie_tooth_disease]].

content.definition: Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) comprises two enveloped dsDNA viruses (HSV-1 and HSV-2) that establish latency in sensory ganglia, causing mucocutaneous lesions and severe CNS complications like encephalitis and meningitis.
content.atAGlance:
• HSV-1: Oral lesions (Cold sores). Latent in Trigeminal Ganglia. Causes Temporal Lobe Encephalitis (most common sporadic encephalitis) and Keratoconjunctivitis.
  • HSV-2: Genital lesions. Latent in Sacral Ganglia. Causes Meningitis (Mollaret's) and Neonatal Herpes.
  • Diagnosis: PCR (CSF), Tzanck smear (multinucleated giant cells - older test).
  • Treatment: [[acyclovir]], Valacyclovir, Famciclovir. Foscarnet for resistant cases.
  • USMLE Tip: Temporal lobe hemorrhage/edema + fever + altered mental status = HSV-1 Encephalitis.
content.takeAway: HSV causes recurrent mucocutaneous infections via latency in sensory ganglia; HSV-1 is the primary cause of sporadic encephalitis (temporal lobe), while HSV-2 causes genital herpes and meningitis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[HSV Infection] --> B[Mucocutaneous Infection]; B --> C[Retrograde Transport]; C --> D[Latency in Sensory Ganglia]; D --> E[Reactivation]; E --> F[Recurrent Lesions]; D -->|HSV-1| G[Encephalitis]; D -->|HSV-2| H[Meningitis];

content.definition: The Hippocampus is a critical structure within the medial temporal lobe [[limbic_system]], essential for the consolidation of short-term memory into long-term memory and spatial navigation.
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Memory consolidation (Papez circuit).
  • Vulnerability: Highly sensitive to Hypoxia (Sommer's sector/CA1). First area damaged in global cerebral ischemia.
  • Pathology:
    - [[alzheimer_disease]]: Early atrophy causing anterograde amnesia.
    - [[wernicke_korsakoff_syndrome]]: Functional disruption (via mammillary bodies).
    - Trauma/Stroke: Bilateral damage → Permanent Anterograde Amnesia (Patient H.M.).
  • USMLE Tip: "Hippocampus acts like a Hippo-compass" (Spatial memory). Bilateral lesions prevent forming new memories.
content.takeAway: The Hippocampus is key for memory formation; it is exquisitely sensitive to hypoxia and is the site of early atrophy in Alzheimer's disease.

content.definition: The Histamine H1 Receptor is a Gq-coupled receptor involved in allergic inflammation (periphery) and arousal/vestibular function (CNS), playing a specific role in stimulating the vomiting center via vestibular input.
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Vestibular system, Nucleus Tractus Solitarius (Vomiting Center), Cortex (Arousal).
  • Function (CNS): Mediates Motion Sickness and wakefulness.
  • Pharmacology:
    - 1st Gen Antagonists: [[diphenhydramine]], Meclizine, Promethazine. Cross BBB. Used for Motion Sickness and vestibular nausea. Cause Sedation.
    - 2nd Gen Antagonists: Loratadine, Cetirizine. Peripherally selective (Allergies).
  • USMLE Tip: For motion sickness, target H1 (and M1) receptors. For Chemo nausea, target 5-HT3/NK1.
content.takeAway: H1 Receptors in the vestibular system drive motion sickness; 1st generation antihistamines (e.g., Diphenhydramine) block these to treat nausea at the cost of sedation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Motion/Vestibular Input] --> B[H1 Receptors in Brainstem]; C[M1 Receptors in Brainstem] --> D[Vomiting Center]; D --> E[Nausea/Emesis]; F[Diphenhydramine] --x|Blocks| B;

content.definition: Holoprosencephaly is a congenital malformation characterized by the failure of the embryonic forebrain (prosencephalon) to cleave into two distinct cerebral hemispheres, resulting in a single ventricle and midline facial defects.
content.atAGlance:
• Timing: Weeks 3-5 of gestation.
  • Etiology: Mutations in [[sonic_hedgehog]] pathway, [[patau_syndrome]] (Trisomy 13), Fetal Alcohol Syndrome.
  • Spectrum:
    - Severe: Cyclopia (one eye), Proboscis, Alobar brain (monoventricle).
    - Mild: Cleft lip/palate, hypotelorism (close eyes), single central incisor.
  • USMLE Tip: "Fused" brain structures (basal ganglia, thalami, ventricle) + Midline facial defects = Holoprosencephaly.
content.takeAway: Holoprosencephaly is a failure of forebrain separation associated with Trisomy 13 and Sonic Hedgehog mutations, presenting with a monoventricle and midline facial anomalies.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Defective SHH Signaling] --> B[Failure of Prosencephalon Cleavage]; B --> C[Fused Cerebral Hemispheres]; C --> D[Monoventricle]; B --> E[Midline Facial Defects];

content.definition: Homer-Wright Rosettes are histologic structures found in certain small blue cell tumors, characterized by tumor cells arranged in a circle around a central meshwork of neuropil (neurites), without a central lumen.
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: Halo of cells surrounding a pink, fibrillary center (neuropil). No true lumen (unlike Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes).
  • Associations:
    - [[medulloblastoma]]: Cerebellar tumor in children.
    - [[neuroblastoma]]: Adrenal tumor in children.
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from Perivascular Pseudorosettes ([[ependymoma]] - cells around a blood vessel) and Flexner-Wintersteiner Rosettes ([[retinoblastoma]] - cells around a true lumen).
content.takeAway: Homer-Wright Rosettes indicate neuroblastic differentiation (neuropil core), classically seen in Medulloblastoma and Neuroblastoma.

content.definition: The Cortical Homunculus is a distorted topographic representation of the human body across the primary motor (precentral gyrus) and sensory (postcentral gyrus) cortices, where the amount of cortex devoted to a body part corresponds to its motor/sensory density.
content.atAGlance:
• Organization:
    - Medial Surface: Leg, Foot, Genitals. (Supplied by [[anterior_cerebral_artery]]).
    - Lateral Surface: Face, Hand, Arm, Tongue. (Supplied by [[middle_cerebral_artery]]).
  • Distortion: Large areas for Face (Lips/Tongue) and Hands; Small areas for Trunk/Legs.
  • Clinical Relevance:
    - ACA Stroke: Contralateral Leg weakness/sensory loss.
    - MCA Stroke: Contralateral Face/Arm weakness/sensory loss.
content.takeAway: The Homunculus maps body function to cortical anatomy; medial lesions (ACA) affect the legs, while lateral lesions (MCA) affect the face and upper extremities.
content.mermaid: graph LR; A[Medial Cortex] --ACA Supply--> B[Leg/Foot]; C[Lateral Cortex] --MCA Supply--> D[Face/Hand/Arm];

content.definition: A Hordeolum (Stye) is an acute, localized, painful infection of an eyelash follicle or sebaceous gland of the eyelid, most commonly caused by [[staphylococcus_aureus]].
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    - External: Infection of Zeis/Moll glands (eyelash follicle).
    - Internal: Infection of Meibomian glands.
  • Clinical Presentation: Erythematous, tender, painful nodule at the lid margin.
  • Treatment: Warm compresses (spontaneous drainage). Antibiotics if cellulitis.
  • Differential: [[chalazion]] (Chronic, Painless, sterile granuloma).
  • USMLE Tip: Hordeolum Hurts. Chalazion is Chill (painless).
content.takeAway: Hordeolum is an acute painful bacterial infection of the eyelid glands, treated conservatively, distinguishing it from the painless chronic chalazion.

content.definition: Horner Syndrome is a clinical triad of ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis caused by the interruption of the oculosympathetic pathway anywhere along its three-neuron chain.
content.atAGlance:
• Triad:
    1. Ptosis: Mild drooping (Superior Tarsal muscle paralysis).
    2. Miosis: Constricted pupil (Loss of dilator pupillae tone).
    3. Anhidrosis: Loss of sweating on ipsilateral face.
  • Pathway & Lesions:
    - 1st Neuron (Central): Hypothalamus to T1. ([[lateral_medullary_syndrome]], [[syringomyelia]]).
    - 2nd Neuron (Preganglionic): T1 to Superior Cervical Ganglion. ([[pancoast_tumor]]).
    - 3rd Neuron (Postganglionic): SCG to Eye. ([[carotid_artery_dissection]]). *Anhidrosis absent if lesion is distal to carotid bifurcation.*
  • Diagnosis: Cocaine test (No dilation). [[apraclonidine]] test (Dilation - hypersensitivity).
  • USMLE Tip: Pancoast Tumor (Apex of lung) + Horner's = Compression of Stellate Ganglion/Sympathetic chain.
content.takeAway: Horner Syndrome localizes to the sympathetic chain; identifying the level (Central vs. Preganglionic vs. Postganglionic) helps identify the etiology (Stroke vs. Tumor vs. Dissection).
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypothalamus] -->|1st Neuron| B[Spinal Cord T1]; B -->|2nd Neuron| C[Superior Cervical Ganglion]; C -->|3rd Neuron| D[Pupil Dilation/Lid Elevation];

content.definition: Hypothalamic Appetite Regulation involves the interplay between the Lateral Hypothalamus (Hunger center) and the Ventromedial Hypothalamus (Satiety center), regulated by hormones like Ghrelin and Leptin.
content.atAGlance:
• Lateral Hypothalamus (LH):
    - Function: Stimulates Hunger.
    - Regulation: Stimulated by [[ghrelin]]; Inhibited by [[leptin]].
    - Lesion: Anorexia, failure to thrive. "Lateral injury makes you Lean."
  • Ventromedial Hypothalamus (VMH):
    - Function: Stimulates Satiety.
    - Regulation: Stimulated by [[leptin]].
    - Lesion: Hyperphagia, Obesity. "Ventromedial injury makes you Very Massive."
    - Etiology: [[craniopharyngioma]], [[prader_willi_syndrome]].
content.takeAway: The Hypothalamus balances hunger (Lateral) and satiety (Ventromedial); lesions disrupt this balance leading to starvation or obesity, respectively.
content.mermaid: graph LR; A[Ghrelin] --(+)--> B[Lateral Hypothalamus]; B --> C[Hunger]; D[Leptin] --(-)--> B; D --(+)--> E[Ventromedial Hypothalamus]; E --> F[Satiety];

content.definition: Huntington Disease is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disorder caused by a CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene, leading to the atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen.
content.atAGlance:
• Genetics: CAG repeats on Chromosome 4. Autosomal Dominant. Demonstrates Anticipation (worsens in subsequent generations).
  • Pathophysiology: Mutant huntingtin protein causes excitotoxicity (NMDA) and loss of GABAergic neurons in the [[striatum]] ([[caudate_nucleus]] > putamen).
  • Neurotransmitters: Decreased GABA, Decreased ACh, Increased Dopamine.
  • Clinical Features:
    - Motor: [[chorea]] (dance-like movements), Athetosis.
    - Psychiatric: Depression, Aggression, Psychosis.
    - Cognitive: Dementia.
  • Imaging: Caudate atrophy causes enlargement of frontal horns of lateral ventricles ("Boxcar Ventricles").
  • USMLE Tip: "Caudate loss, ACh/GABA loss, Genetic repeats (CAG) on Chr 4."
content.takeAway: Huntington Disease is a genetic striatal degeneration characterized by chorea and dementia, driven by the toxic gain of function of CAG repeats leading to GABAergic neuron loss.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[CAG Expansion] --> B[Mutant Huntingtin]; B --> C[Neuronal Death in Caudate]; C --> D[Loss of GABA/ACh]; C --> E[Relative Dopamine Excess]; E --> F[Chorea];

content.definition: Hydrocephalus is a pathological accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) within the ventricular system, leading to ventricular dilation and elevated [[intracranial_pressure]].
content.atAGlance:
• Types:
    1. [[communicating_hydrocephalus]]: Impaired resorption (Arachnoid granulations). All ventricles dilated.
    2. [[noncommunicating_hydrocephalus]] (Obstructive): Structural block (e.g., Aqueduct). Upstream ventricles dilated.
    3. [[normal_pressure_hydrocephalus]]: Periodic pressure spikes. Wet/Wobbly/Wacky triad.
    4. [[ex_vacuo_ventriculomegaly]]: Brain atrophy (Alzheimer's). Normal pressure.
  • Clinical: Headache, Papilledema, Macrocephaly (infants), Herniation risk.
  • Treatment: Ventriculoperitoneal (VP) shunt, Endoscopic Third Ventriculostomy.
content.takeAway: Hydrocephalus results from an imbalance in CSF production, flow, or resorption; distinguishing communicating vs. non-communicating types guides etiology and management.

content.definition: (Placeholder) A metabolic disorder characterized by elevated serum calcium levels, often due to hyperparathyroidism or malignancy, referenced in the graph awaiting detailed population.
content.atAGlance: • See [[succinylcholine]] (causes hyperkalemia, not hypercalcemia, though often confused), [[sarcoidosis]], [[multiple_myeloma]].

content.definition: (Placeholder) A state of increased tendency for blood thrombosis, referenced in the context of venous sinus thrombosis and specific syndromes.
content.atAGlance: • See [[factor_v_leiden]], [[antiphospholipid_syndrome]], [[dural_venous_sinuses]].

content.definition: (Placeholder) Severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy resulting in weight loss and electrolyte imbalance.
content.atAGlance: • Referenced in context of antiemetic use.

content.definition: Hyperprolactinemia is a state of elevated serum [[prolactin]], often caused by a pituitary adenoma or dopamine antagonists (antipsychotics), leading to galactorrhea and hypogonadism via GnRH suppression.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Prolactin inhibits [[gonadotropin_releasing_hormone]] (GnRH) → Decreased FSH/LH → Hypogonadism.
  • Etiologies: [[pituitary_adenoma]] (Prolactinoma), [[antipsychotics]] (Dopamine blockade), Hypothyroidism (TRH stimulates Prolactin), Pregnancy.
  • Clinical Features: Galactorrhea, Amenorrhea, Infertility, Libido loss.
  • Treatment: Dopamine Agonists ([[cabergoline]], [[bromocriptine]]).
  • USMLE Tip: Tuberoinfundibular pathway blockade by antipsychotics causes this side effect.
content.takeAway: Hyperprolactinemia suppresses the reproductive axis (GnRH) and is commonly caused by prolactinomas or dopamine-blocking drugs; treat with dopamine agonists.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Dopamine Antagonist] --x|Blocks Inhibition| B[Lactotrophs]; B --> C[Increased Prolactin]; C --x|Inhibits| D[GnRH]; D --> E[Decreased FSH/LH]; E --> F[Hypogonadism];

content.definition: (Placeholder) Chronic elevation of systemic arterial blood pressure, serving as a major risk factor for stroke, retinopathy, and aneurysm formation.
content.atAGlance: • See [[hypertensive_retinopathy]], [[charcot_bouchard_microaneurysm]], [[intraparenchymal_hemorrhage]], [[lacunar_stroke]].

content.definition: Hypertensive Retinopathy is retinal vascular damage caused by chronic and/or malignant [[hypertension]], characterized by arteriolar sclerosis, flame hemorrhages, and optic disc edema.
content.atAGlance:
• Chronic Changes: Arteriolar narrowing, AV Nicking (arteriole compresses vein), Copper/Silver wiring (sclerosis).
  • Acute/Malignant Changes: [[cotton_wool_spots]] (ischemia), Flame hemorrhages, Hard Exudates (lipid leak).
  • Macular Star: Exudates radiating from the macula.
  • Papilledema: Swelling of the optic disc; indicates Hypertensive Emergency.
  • USMLE Tip: "AV Nicking" implies chronic hypertension. "Papilledema" implies malignant/emergency hypertension.
content.takeAway: Hypertensive Retinopathy manifests as vascular sclerosis (wiring, nicking) in chronic stages and ischemia/leakage (cotton-wool spots, papilledema) in acute malignant stages.

content.definition: (Placeholder) A genetic disorder of the heart muscle characterized by thickening of the ventricular wall; noted here for its association with Friedreich Ataxia.
content.atAGlance: • See [[friedreich_ataxia]].

content.definition: Therapeutic Hyperventilation is a maneuver used to acutely lower [[intracranial_pressure]] by reducing arterial PCO2, which induces cerebral vasoconstriction and decreases cerebral blood volume.
content.atAGlance:
• Mechanism: ↓ PCO2 (Hypocapnia) → Cerebral Vasoconstriction → ↓ Cerebral Blood Flow/Volume → ↓ ICP.
  • Indication: Acute herniation syndromes (bridge to definitive therapy).
  • Trigger for Seizures: Hyperventilation is a potent trigger for [[absence_seizure]] (3 Hz spike-and-wave).
  • Physiology: Cerebral perfusion is linearly responsive to PCO2 between 20-80 mmHg.
  • USMLE Tip: Effect is temporary (CSF pH equilibrates). Prolonged use risks ischemia.
content.takeAway: Hyperventilation reduces intracranial pressure via CO2-mediated vasoconstriction and is also a diagnostic trigger for absence seizures.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hyperventilation] --> B[Decreased pCO2]; B --> C[Cerebral Vasoconstriction]; C --> D[Decreased Cerebral Blood Volume]; D --> E[Decreased Intracranial Pressure];

content.definition: The Hypoglossal Nerve (CN XII) is a purely motor cranial nerve originating in the medulla that innervates all intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue (except the palatoglossus).
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Hypoglossal nucleus in the midline Medulla.
  • Exit: Hypoglossal canal.
  • Vascular Relation: Exits near the [[anterior_spinal_artery]] and Vertebral artery (Medial Medullary Syndrome).
  • Function: Tongue movement (Genioglossus protrudes tongue).
  • Lesion (LMN): Tongue deviates toward the side of the lesion ("Lick your wounds"). Atrophy and fasciculations present.
  • USMLE Tip: Medial Medullary Syndrome involves CN XII (Tongue deviation) + Corticospinal (Hemiparesis) + Medial Lemniscus (Proprioception).
content.takeAway: CN XII drives tongue movement; damage causes deviation toward the lesion side, and its medial location in the medulla makes it a key localizing sign in Medial Medullary Syndrome.

content.definition: Hypopyon is the accumulation of pus (leukocytes) in the anterior chamber of the eye, typically settling at the bottom due to gravity, indicating severe anterior [[uveitis]] or endophthalmitis.
content.atAGlance:
• Appearance: White/yellowish fluid level in the inferior anterior chamber.
  • Etiologies:
    - Infectious: Bacterial keratitis, Endophthalmitis.
    - Inflammatory: HLA-B27 associated [[uveitis]] (Ankylosing spondylitis, Reiter's), Behçet syndrome.
  • USMLE Tip: Often associated with a red, painful eye and photophobia. Marker of severe inflammation.
content.takeAway: Hypopyon is a layering of white blood cells in the anterior chamber, a sign of intense intraocular inflammation (uveitis) or infection.

content.definition: The Hypothalamus is the central regulator of homeostasis, autonomic function, and the endocrine system, located in the diencephalon below the thalamus and connected to the pituitary gland.
content.atAGlance:
• Functions (TAN HATS): Thirst/Water, Adenohypophysis control, Neurohypophysis release, Hunger, Autonomic reg, Temperature, Sexual urges.
  • Key Nuclei:
    - Lateral: Hunger (inhibited by [[leptin]]). Lesion → Anorexia.
    - Ventromedial: Satiety (stimulated by Leptin). Lesion → Hyperphagia/Obesity.
    - Anterior: Cooling (Parasympathetic). Lesion → Hyperthermia.
    - Posterior: Heating (Sympathetic). Lesion → Poikilothermia.
    - Suprachiasmatic: Circadian rhythm.
    - Supraoptic/Paraventricular: ADH/Oxytocin.
  • USMLE Tip: "Lateral injury makes you Lean. Ventromedial injury makes you Very Massive."
content.takeAway: The Hypothalamus maintains body homeostasis through specific nuclei controlling hunger, temperature, circadian rhythms, and pituitary hormone secretion.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Hypothalamus] --> B[Lateral Nucleus (Hunger)]; A --> C[Ventromedial Nucleus (Satiety)]; A --> D[Anterior Nucleus (Cooling)]; A --> E[Posterior Nucleus (Heating)]; A --> F[SCN (Rhythm)];

content.definition: Hypoxic Stroke is a type of ischemic stroke caused by systemic hypoperfusion or hypoxemia (rather than local thrombosis/embolism), leading to diffuse injury that preferentially affects the highly vulnerable watershed areas between major arterial territories.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiology: Cardiac arrest, severe hypotension (shock), or severe hypoxemia.
  • Vulnerable Areas: [[watershed_zones]] (border zones between ACA/MCA and MCA/PCA territories).
  • Clinical Presentation:
    - ACA-MCA Watershed: Proximal upper/lower extremity weakness ("Man-in-a-barrel" syndrome).
    - PCA-MCA Watershed: Higher-order visual dysfunction.
  • Pathology: Laminar necrosis of the cortex; hippocampus and Purkinje cells are most sensitive.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a patient with a history of cardiac arrest who wakes up with proximal weakness (shoulders/thighs) sparing the face/hands.
content.takeAway: Hypoxic Stroke results from systemic hypoperfusion, damaging the "watershed" border zones between major cerebral arteries, causing specific deficits like "man-in-a-barrel" syndrome.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Systemic Hypotension] --> B[Decreased Perfusion Pressure]; B --> C[Ischemia in Distal Arterial Beds]; C --> D[Watershed Infarction]; D --> E[Proximal Limb Weakness];

content.definition: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension (Pseudotumor Cerebri) is a condition of elevated intracranial pressure in the absence of a tumor or hydrocephalus, classically affecting obese women of childbearing age and presenting with headaches and papilledema.
content.atAGlance:
• Risk Factors: Female, Fat, Forty (Fertile). Medications: Tetracyclines, Vitamin A (Isotretinoin), Danazol.
  • Clinical Features: Pulsatile headache, Tinnitus ("whooshing"), Diplopia (CN VI palsy), Papilledema.
  • Diagnosis:
    - MRI: Normal brain, empty sella.
    - Lumbar Puncture: High opening pressure (>25 cm H2O) with normal CSF composition. Note: LP is also therapeutic (relieves headache).
  • Treatment: Weight loss (First line), [[acetazolamide]] (decreases CSF production), Topiramate. Shunt or Optic Nerve Sheath Fenestration for vision threat.
  • USMLE Tip: "Female TOAD" (Tetracyclines, Obesity, vitamin A, Danazol).
content.takeAway: Idiopathic Intracranial Hypertension is a diagnosis of exclusion in obese women with headache and papilledema, managed with weight loss and acetazolamide to prevent vision loss.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Risk Factors e.g. Obesity] --> B[Increased Intracranial Pressure]; B --> C[Papilledema]; B --> D[Headache/Tinnitus]; B --> E[CN VI Palsy]; F[Lumbar Puncture] -->|Relieves| B;

content.definition: Increased Intracranial Pressure (ICP) is a dangerous elevation of pressure within the cranium due to mass effect (tumor, blood) or fluid accumulation (edema, hydrocephalus), which compromises cerebral perfusion and risks brain herniation.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiologies: Tumors, [[cerebral_edema]], [[hydrocephalus]], Intracranial Hemorrhage, [[idiopathic_intracranial_hypertension]], Venous sinus thrombosis.
  • Clinical Findings: Headache (worse in morning/lying down), Vomiting, [[papilledema]], [[cushing_reflex]] (HTN, Bradycardia, Irregular respiration).
  • Complications: [[brain_herniation]] (Uncal, Tonsillar, Subfalcine), Brain death (CPP = 0).
  • Management: Elevate head, Hyperventilation (vasoconstriction), Mannitol, Surgical decompression.
  • USMLE Tip: Cushing Triad = Hypertension + Bradycardia + Irregular breathing = Impending Herniation.
content.takeAway: Increased ICP is a medical emergency characterized by headache, papilledema, and the Cushing reflex, requiring immediate intervention to maintain cerebral perfusion and prevent herniation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Mass/Fluid] --> B[Increased ICP]; B --> C[Decreased Cerebral Perfusion]; C --> D[Cushing Reflex]; B --> E[Brain Herniation];

content.definition: The Incus ("Anvil") is the middle bone of the three auditory ossicles in the middle ear, transmitting vibrations from the [[malleus]] to the [[stapes]].
content.atAGlance:
• Location: Middle Ear.
  • Articulation: Synovial joints with the Malleus (lateral) and Stapes (medial).
  • Embryology: Derived from the 1st Pharyngeal Arch (Neural Crest).
  • Function: Impedance matching (amplifies sound energy from air to fluid).
  • Pathology: Disruption (trauma) or fixation (otosclerosis) leads to [[conductive_hearing_loss]].
content.takeAway: The Incus is the bridge of the ossicular chain, derived from the 1st pharyngeal arch, essential for conducting sound to the inner ear.
content.mermaid: graph LR; A[Tympanic Membrane] --> B[Malleus]; B --> C[Incus]; C --> D[Stapes]; D --> E[Oval Window];

content.definition: The Indirect Pathway of the basal ganglia suppresses unwanted movement by increasing the inhibitory output of the GPi/SNr to the thalamus, modulated by [[dopamine]] binding to D2 receptors.
content.atAGlance:
• Circuitry: Cortex → Striatum (GABA) → Inhibits GPe → Disinhibits [[subthalamic_nucleus]] → Excites GPi/SNr → Inhibits Thalamus → Decreased Motion.
  • Dopamine Effect: Nigrostriatal dopamine binds D2 Receptors (Gi - inhibitory) in the striatum → Inhibits the Indirect Pathway → Allows movement.
  • Pathology:
    - Loss of D2 stimulation (Parkinson's): Indirect pathway runs wild → rigidity/bradykinesia.
    - Loss of Indirect Pathway (Huntington's): Early loss of striatal GABA/Enk neurons → Hyperkinesia (Chorea).
  • Mnemonic: Indirect = Inhibits movement. D2 = Inhibition.
content.takeAway: The Indirect Pathway acts as a brake on movement; dopamine lifts this brake via D2 receptors. Loss of this pathway leads to chorea (Huntington's), while overactivity leads to parkinsonism.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Cortex] --(+)--> B[Striatum]; B --(-)|GABA| C[GPe]; C --(-)|GABA| D[Subthalamic Nucleus]; D --(+)|Glutamate| E[GPi/SNr]; E --(-)|GABA| F[Thalamus]; F --(+)|Glutamate| G[Motor Cortex]; H[SNc Dopamine] --(-)|D2| B;

content.definition: Infective Dementia refers to cognitive decline caused by transmissible agents affecting the CNS, including viruses (HIV), spirochetes (Syphilis), and prions (CJD).
content.atAGlance:
• [[hiv_associated_dementia]]: Subcortical dementia, microglial nodules, multinucleated giant cells.
  • [[creutzfeldt_jakob_disease]]: Prion disease. Rapidly progressive, myoclonus, spongiform changes.
  • Neurosyphilis: [[tabes_dorsalis]], General Paresis ("Paretic Neurosyphilis" - dementia, personality changes). Argyll Robertson pupil.
  • PML: JC virus in immunocompromised. White matter lesions.
content.takeAway: Infective Dementia includes treatable (Syphilis, HIV) and untreatable (Prion) causes; rapid progression suggests CJD, while HIV presents as a subcortical pattern.

content.definition: The Inferior Oblique Muscle is an extraocular muscle innervated by the [[oculomotor_nerve]] (CN III) that primarily extorts and elevates the eye (especially when adducted).
content.atAGlance:
• Innervation: CN III (Oculomotor).
  • Primary Action: Extorsion (rotates top of eye outward).
  • Secondary Actions: Elevation (looking up), Abduction.
  • Testing: Have the patient look In (Adduct) and Up. ("I O U" = Inferior Oblique Up).
  • USMLE Tip: Unlike the Recti muscles, the Obliques act contrary to their names regarding vertical movement (Inferior → Elevates, Superior → Depresses).
content.takeAway: The Inferior Oblique elevates the eye when it is adducted and is tested by looking "In and Up"; it is innervated by CN III.

content.definition: The Inferior Rectus Muscle is an extraocular muscle innervated by the [[oculomotor_nerve]] (CN III) that primarily depresses the eye (especially when abducted).
content.atAGlance:
• Innervation: CN III (Oculomotor).
  • Primary Action: Depression (looking down).
  • Secondary Actions: Extorsion, Adduction.
  • Testing: Have the patient look Out (Abduct) and Down.
  • Pathology: Entrapment in [[blowout_fracture]] of the orbital floor leads to restriction of upward gaze (tethering) and vertical diplopia.
content.takeAway: The Inferior Rectus depresses the eye and is clinically significant for its frequent entrapment in orbital floor fractures, limiting upgaze.

content.definition: Inhaled Anesthetics are volatile liquids or gases used to maintain general anesthesia, characterized by their solubility properties (Blood/Gas and Oil/Gas coefficients) and potency (MAC).
content.atAGlance:
• Agents: [[desflurane]], [[isoflurane]], [[sevoflurane]], [[halothane]], Nitrous Oxide (N2O).
  • Properties:
    - Blood/Gas Partition Coefficient: Determines speed of induction/recovery. Low solubility (Desflurane) = Fast. High (Halothane) = Slow.
    - Oil/Gas Partition Coefficient: Determines potency. High lipid solubility = High potency = Low MAC.
  • Adverse Effects: [[malignant_hyperthermia]] (except N2O), Hepatotoxicity (Halothane), Nephrotoxicity (Methoxyflurane), Respiratory depression, Increased cerebral blood flow (Increased ICP).
  • USMLE Tip: MAC is inversely proportional to Potency.
content.takeAway: Inhaled Anesthetics are defined by MAC (potency) and solubility (speed); they carry a class risk of Malignant Hyperthermia and increasing intracranial pressure.

content.definition: The Inner Ear (Labyrinth) is located within the petrous temporal bone and contains the organs of hearing ([[cochlea]]) and balance (Vestibular system: Semicircular canals, Utricle, Saccule).
content.atAGlance:
• Bony Labyrinth: Filled with Perilymph (High Na+, Low K+ - like ECF).
  • Membranous Labyrinth: Filled with Endolymph (High K+, Low Na+ - like ICF).
  • Structures:
    - [[cochlea]]: Hearing (Organ of Corti).
    - Vestibule (Utricle/Saccule): Linear acceleration/Gravity.
    - Semicircular Canals: Rotational acceleration.
  • Pathology: [[meniere_disease]] (Endolymphatic hydrops), Labyrinthitis, BPPV (Otoliths).
content.takeAway: The Inner Ear houses the sensory apparatus for hearing and balance within fluid-filled compartments (Endolymph/Perilymph), innervated by CN VIII.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Inner Ear] --> B[Cochlea]; A --> C[Vestibular System]; B --> D[Hearing]; C --> E[Semicircular Canals]; C --> F[Otolith Organs]; E --> G[Rotation]; F --> H[Linear Motion/Gravity];

content.definition: Insomnia Therapy involves a range of pharmacologic agents targeting GABA, Melatonin, or Orexin receptors to induce or maintain sleep.
content.atAGlance:
• GABAA Modulators (Z-drugs): [[zolpidem]], [[eszopiclone]], Zaleplon. Selective for BZ1 subtype. Less tolerance than benzos. Reversible by Flumazenil.
  • Orexin Antagonists: [[suvorexant]]. Blocks wakefulness (contraindicated in Narcolepsy).
  • Melatonin Agonists: [[ramelteon]]. Binds MT1/MT2 in Suprachiasmatic nucleus. Safe in elderly (no dependence).
  • Others: Trazodone, Antihistamines (Diphenhydramine).
  • USMLE Tip: For elderly patients, Ramelteon is safest. Avoid Diphenhydramine (anticholinergic delirium) and Benzos (falls).
content.takeAway: Pharmacotherapy for insomnia targets sleep-wake pathways via GABA (Z-drugs), Melatonin (Ramelteon), or Orexin (Suvorexant), with selection based on side effect profile and duration.

content.definition: Intention Tremor is a slow, zigzagging tremor of the extremities that worsens as the limb approaches a target, serving as a classic sign of cerebellar dysfunction.
content.atAGlance:
• Localization: Ipsilateral Cerebellar Hemisphere (specifically the Dentate Nucleus or Superior Cerebellar Peduncle).
  • Characteristics: Absent at rest. Amplitude increases during guided movement (kinetic tremor) and peaks at the target.
  • Test: Finger-to-Nose test (patient overshoots/undershoots and shakes near the nose).
  • Etiologies: [[multiple_sclerosis]] (Charcot Triad), Stroke, Alcohol use disorder (chronic).
  • Differentiation: Contrast with Resting Tremor (Parkinson's - improves with movement) and Essential Tremor (Action tremor - present throughout movement).
content.takeAway: Intention Tremor indicates cerebellar pathology (hemisphere/dentate), characterized by worsening oscillation as the target is approached.

content.definition: The Internal Carotid Artery (ICA) is a major artery supplying the anterior brain circulation, known for its tortuous course through the Cavernous Sinus where it is intimately associated with cranial nerve VI.
content.atAGlance:
• Course: Neck → Carotid Canal → Cavernous Sinus (Cavernous Segment) → Cerebral Circle of Willis.
  • Relations: Inside the Cavernous Sinus, it runs adjacent to [[abducens_nerve]] (CN VI). Postganglionic sympathetic fibers run along its surface.
  • Branches: Ophthalmic Artery, PCom, Anterior Choroidal, Bifurcates into ACA and MCA.
  • Pathology:
    - Aneurysm (Cavernous): Can compress CN VI (isolated lateral rectus palsy).
    - Dissection: Painful Horner Syndrome (disrupts sympathetics).
    - Fistula: [[carotid_cavernous_fistula]].
content.takeAway: The Internal Carotid Artery supplies the anterior circulation and passes through the cavernous sinus, where pathology can cause specific deficits like CN VI palsy or Horner syndrome.

content.definition: The Internal Jugular Vein is the primary venous outflow tract for the brain, receiving blood from the [[dural_venous_sinuses]] (specifically the sigmoid sinus) at the jugular foramen.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Continuation of the Sigmoid Sinus at the Jugular Foramen.
  • Course: Descends in the Carotid Sheath (with ICA/Common Carotid and Vagus Nerve).
  • Drainage: Brain, Face, Neck.
  • Clinical: Site for central venous catheterization. Distension reflects Right Atrial Pressure (JVP).
content.takeAway: The Internal Jugular Vein drains the dural venous sinuses, exiting the skull via the jugular foramen to return CNS blood to the systemic circulation.

content.definition: Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO) is a conjugate gaze palsy caused by a lesion in the Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF), characterized by impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye and dissociated nystagmus of the contralateral abducting eye during horizontal gaze.
content.atAGlance:
• Lesion Localization: Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF) in the dorsomedial Pons/Midbrain.
  • Mechanism: Disruption of the signal from the contralateral Abducens (CN VI) nucleus to the ipsilateral Oculomotor (CN III) medial rectus subnucleus.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    - Adducting Eye: Paresis (cannot look medially).
    - Abducting Eye: Horizontal nystagmus (correctional saccades).
    - Convergence: Usually preserved (cortical input to CN III bypasses MLF).
  • Etiologies:
    - Bilateral: Highly suggestive of [[multiple_sclerosis]] (young patient).
    - Unilateral: Often lacunar stroke (elderly patient).
  • USMLE Tip: "Right INO" means the Right eye cannot adduct (Right MLF lesion).
content.takeAway: INO is a disconnection syndrome of the MLF resulting in adduction failure and contralateral nystagmus; bilateral presentation strongly suggests Multiple Sclerosis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Lateral Gaze Command] --> B[Contralateral PPRF]; B --> C[Contralateral CN VI Nucleus]; C --> D[Contralateral Lateral Rectus (Abducts)]; C --x|Lesion in MLF| E[Ipsilateral CN III Nucleus]; E --> F[Ipsilateral Medial Rectus (Fails to Adduct)];

content.definition: Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage is a subtype of hemorrhagic stroke involving bleeding directly into the brain tissue, most commonly caused by the rupture of small penetrating arteries due to chronic hypertension or amyloid angiopathy.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiologies:
    - Hypertensive: Rupture of [[charcot_bouchard_microaneurysm]]. Affects deep structures: Basal Ganglia (Putamen), Thalamus, Pons, Cerebellum.
    - [[cerebral_amyloid_angiopathy]]: Beta-amyloid deposition in vessels. Affects Lobar (cortical) regions (e.g., Occipital, Parietal). Common in elderly.
    - Other: AVM, Tumor, Coagulopathy, Vasculitis.
  • Clinical Features: Sudden onset focal deficit + Headache, Vomiting, Decreased consciousness (mass effect).
  • Imaging: CT shows hyperdense (white) collection within brain parenchyma.
  • USMLE Tip: Putaminal hemorrhage causes contralateral hemiparesis (Internal Capsule compression). Pontine hemorrhage causes "pinpoint pupils" and coma.
content.takeAway: Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage is usually hypertensive (deep/basal ganglia) or amyloid-related (lobar); it causes rapid mass effect and focal deficits based on location.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Chronic Hypertension] --> B[Lipohyalinosis of Lenticulostriate Arteries]; B --> C[Charcot-Bouchard Microaneurysms]; C --> D[Rupture]; D --> E[Basal Ganglia Hemorrhage];

content.definition: Intravenous Anesthetics are drugs used for the rapid induction of anesthesia (and maintenance in TIVA), acting primarily by potentiating GABAergic inhibition or blocking NMDA excitation.
content.atAGlance:
• [[propofol]]: Potentiates GABAA. Rapid on/off. Anti-emetic. SE: Hypotension, respiratory depression, pain on injection.
  • [[etomidate]]: Potentiates GABAA. Hemodynamically stable. SE: Adrenal suppression.
  • [[ketamine]]: NMDA antagonist. Dissociative anesthesia. Sympathomimetic (increases BP/HR). SE: Hallucinations, emergence delirium.
  • [[barbiturates]] (Thiopental): Potentiates GABAA. Decreases cerebral blood flow/ICP. Highly lipid soluble (redistributes to tissue).
  • [[benzodiazepines]] (Midazolam): Potentiates GABAA. Amnesia/Sedation. Reversal: Flumazenil.
  • Opioids: Adjuncts for analgesia.
content.takeAway: IV Anesthetics allow for rapid induction; Propofol is standard, Etomidate is for hemodynamically unstable patients, and Ketamine provides analgesia/sympathetic boost.
