content.definition: Neonatal Intraventricular Hemorrhage (IVH) is a bleeding into the brain's ventricular system originating from the fragile germinal matrix, predominantly affecting premature and low-birth-weight infants.
content.atAGlance:
• Origin: Germinal Matrix (highly vascularized area in subventricular zone, involutes by term). Fragile vessels rupture due to hypoxia/BP fluctuations.
  • Risk Factors: Prematurity (<32 weeks), Low Birth Weight (<1500g), RDS.
  • Clinical Presentation: Hypotonia, seizures, bulging fontanelle, anemia, apnea. Can be asymptomatic.
  • Complications: Post-hemorrhagic [[hydrocephalus]] (clot obstructs CSF flow), Cerebral Palsy.
  • Screening: Cranial Ultrasound.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for a preemie with sudden drop in hematocrit and altered mental status.
content.takeAway: Intraventricular Hemorrhage is a complication of prematurity caused by the rupture of the fragile germinal matrix capillaries, potentially leading to hydrocephalus and neurodevelopmental delay.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Prematurity] --> B[Fragile Germinal Matrix]; B --> C[Hypoxia/Hemodynamic Stress]; C --> D[Capillary Rupture]; D --> E[Bleeding into Ventricles]; E --> F[Hydrocephalus];

content.definition: Iritis (Anterior Uveitis) is the inflammation of the iris and anterior ciliary body, characterized by eye pain, photophobia, redness (ciliary flush), and the presence of leukocytes in the anterior chamber.
content.atAGlance:
• Clinical Features:
    - Pain, Photophobia, Redness (perilimbal injection).
    - [[hypopyon]] (pus in anterior chamber).
    - Irregular pupil (synechiae - adhesions between iris and lens/cornea).
  • Associations:
    - [[hla_b27]] Spondyloarthropathies: Ankylosing Spondylitis, Reactive Arthritis, Psoriatic Arthritis, IBD.
    - Systemic: Sarcoidosis, Syphilis, Tuberculosis, Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (pauciarticular).
  • Treatment: Topical corticosteroids, Cycloplegics (reduce pain/synechiae).
content.takeAway: Iritis presents with a painful red eye and photophobia; it is a key ocular manifestation of HLA-B27 spondyloarthropathies and sarcoidosis.

content.definition: Iron is an essential mineral required for the synthesis of hemoglobin, myoglobin, and cytochromes, with its metabolism tightly regulated by absorption in the duodenum and storage as ferritin.
content.atAGlance:
• Absorption: Duodenum (as Fe2+). Enhanced by Vitamin C; Inhibited by tannins/tea. Regulated by Hepcidin (blocks ferroportin).
  • Transport: Transferrin (transports Fe3+ in blood).
  • Storage: Ferritin (primary), Hemosiderin (macrophage degradation product).
  • Pathology:
    - Deficiency: [[iron_deficiency_anemia]] (Microcytic, Low Ferritin, High TIBC).
    - Overload: [[hemochromatosis]] (Bronze diabetes, cirrhosis, cardiomyopathy).
    - Toxicity: Acute poisoning (GI bleeding, metabolic acidosis). Treat with [[deferoxamine]].
  • USMLE Tip: "Iron OUT" (High TIBC/Transferrin) in deficiency. "Iron IN" (Low TIBC) in chronic disease/overload.
content.takeAway: Iron is critical for oxygen transport; deficiency leads to microcytic anemia, while overload (Hemochromatosis) causes multiorgan damage due to free radical generation.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Dietary Iron] --> B[Absorption in Duodenum]; B --> C[Transferrin Transport]; C --> D[Bone Marrow (Heme Synthesis)]; C --> E[Storage (Ferritin)]; F[Hepcidin] --x|Blocks| B;

content.definition: Ischemic Stroke is the acute loss of neurologic function due to compromised blood flow to the brain, leading to tissue infarction via thrombotic, embolic, or hypoxic mechanisms.
content.atAGlance:
• Etiologies:
    - Thrombotic: Clot forms in situ (e.g., atherosclerosis). Stuttering onset.
    - Embolic: Clot from elsewhere (e.g., A-fib, Carotids). Sudden onset.
    - Hypoxic: Global hypoperfusion (e.g., Shock). Affects [[watershed_zones]].
  • Histology Timeline:
    - 12-24h: Red Neurons (eosinophilic cytoplasm, pyknotic nuclei).
    - 1-3 days: Neutrophils + Necrosis.
    - 3-7 days: Macrophages (microglia).
    - 1-2 weeks: Reactive Gliosis + Vascular proliferation.
    - >2 weeks: Glial Scar (cystic cavity).
  • Treatment: tPA (if <3-4.5h), Thrombectomy, Aspirin.
  • USMLE Tip: Diffusion-Weighted MRI (DWI) detects ischemia within minutes (bright signal). CT is to rule out hemorrhage.
content.takeAway: Ischemic Stroke causes liquefactive necrosis of brain tissue, evolving from Red Neurons to a fluid-filled cystic space walled off by gliosis.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Vascular Occlusion] --> B[Ischemia]; B --> C[ATP Depletion]; C --> D[Cytotoxic Edema]; B --> E[Red Neurons (12h)]; E --> F[Neutrophils (1-3d)]; F --> G[Macrophages (3-7d)]; G --> H[Glial Scar];

content.definition: Isoflurane is a halogenated ether inhaled anesthetic commonly used for maintenance of general anesthesia, characterized by a pungent odor and intermediate solubility.
content.atAGlance:
• Properties: Pungent odor (limits use for induction). Intermediate blood/gas solubility.
  • Mechanism: Potentiates GABAA receptors.
  • Adverse Effects: Airway irritation (coughing/breath holding), Respiratory depression, Hypotension (vasodilation), Increased intracranial pressure.
  • Class Effect: Can trigger [[malignant_hyperthermia]] in susceptible individuals (Ryanodine receptor mutation).
  • USMLE Tip: Halogenated anesthetics (ending in -flurane) + Succinylcholine are the triggers for Malignant Hyperthermia.
content.takeAway: Isoflurane is a standard maintenance anesthetic that shares the class risk of triggering malignant hyperthermia.

content.definition: JC Virus (John Cunningham Virus) is a Polyomavirus (dsDNA, non-enveloped) that is ubiquitous and latent in most adults but reactivates in immunocompromised states (AIDS CD4 < 200) to cause [[progressive_multifocal_leukoencephalopathy]].
content.atAGlance:
• Pathogenesis: Reactivation → Infection/Lysis of [[oligodendrocytes]] → Demyelination.
  • Disease: Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML).
  • Clinical: Rapidly progressive focal neurologic deficits (weakness, visual field defects, ataxia, dementia). Usually fatal.
  • Imaging: MRI shows multifocal, non-enhancing white matter lesions (no mass effect).
  • USMLE Tip: "JC" = Junky Cerebrum (Demyelination). Don't confuse with BK virus (Bad Kidney - transplant nephropathy).
content.takeAway: JC Virus targets oligodendrocytes in immunosuppressed patients, causing the fatal demyelinating disease PML.
content.mermaid: graph TD; A[Immunosuppression] --> B[JC Virus Reactivation]; B --> C[Infection of Oligodendrocytes]; C --> D[Demyelination]; D --> E[Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy];

content.definition: The Jaw Jerk Reflex is a monosynaptic stretch reflex of the masseter muscle, mediated by the Trigeminal Nerve (CN V3); it is normally absent or minimal, and its presence/hyperactivity indicates an Upper Motor Neuron lesion above the mid-pons.
content.atAGlance:
• Afferent Limb: Sensory V3 (Muscle spindles in Masseter) → Mesencephalic Nucleus of V.
  • Efferent Limb: Motor V3 → Masseter contraction.
  • Testing: Tap on chin with mouth slightly open.
  • Significance: Hyperactive (brisk closure) suggests bilateral supranuclear (UMN) pathology (e.g., [[pseudobulbar_palsy]], ALS).
  • USMLE Tip: A brisk jaw jerk differentiates ALS (UMN bulbar signs) from simple bulbar palsy (LMN only).
content.takeAway: The Jaw Jerk Reflex evaluates the trigeminal nerve and brainstem; hyperactivity serves as a sign of upper motor neuron dysfunction affecting the corticobulbar tracts.

content.definition: (Placeholder) Anatomical structures facilitating movement between bones, susceptible to inflammatory, degenerative, and neuropathic pathologies.
content.atAGlance: • See [[osteoarthritis]], [[rheumatoid_arthritis]], [[charcot_joint]], [[septic_arthritis]], [[gout]].

content.definition: Intraocular Pressure (IOP) is the fluid pressure inside the eye, determined by the balance between aqueous humor production (ciliary body) and drainage (trabecular meshwork/uveoscleral outflow), serving as the primary modifiable risk factor for [[glaucoma]].
content.atAGlance:
• Normal Range: 10-21 mmHg.
  • Regulation:
    - Production: Carbonic anhydrase, Beta-receptors.
    - Outflow: Trabecular meshwork (M3 receptors open it), Uveoscleral pathway (Prostaglandins).
  • Pathology: Elevated IOP compresses the optic nerve head → Glaucomatous optic neuropathy.
  • Pharmacology: Targeted by Beta-blockers, Alpha-agonists, CAIs (decrease production) and Prostaglandins, Cholinomimetics (increase outflow).
content.takeAway: Intraocular Pressure dynamics underpin the pathophysiology and treatment of glaucoma; therapies aim to lower IOP to prevent optic nerve damage.
